description: In the CHFI series, Daniel and Adam will take you through all the concepts, tools, and best-practices you'll need to know for the CHFI exam. You'll be introduced to many different digital forensic techniques and duties like safely copying hard drives, how to perform as a "First Responder", searching for and recovering deleted files, steganographic techniques, common attack avenues, acting as an expert witness, and much more.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam finish their introduction to Computer Forensics by exploring the differences between corporate incidents, which may not require an immediate response from a law enforcement agency, vs computer crimes that would require the immediate intervention of a law enforcement agency. They also cover how you can report a cyber crime to Computer Emergency Response Teams.

Things like that.

00:08:24.250 --> 00:08:27.280

00:08:29.800 --> 00:08:34.420

And so

811

00:36:42.890 --> 00:36:44.900

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam discuss what's involved in a search & seizure both with and without a warrant. They explain how knowing the laws for the area you're in is crucial, as well as the use of technology to perform a search & seizure.

>> My expectation is that that it is

they don't own my bagpack,

I have a reasonable right to assume
tat no one can just rifle through it,

I would even think maybe I have

unless they had some sort of

00:04:41.140 --> 00:04:42.140
>> So you know, it's interesting.

00:04:42.140 --> 00:04:43.250
It would depend, right?

00:04:43.250 --> 00:04:45.970
And one of the things

with regards to reasonable expectation of

But it's interesting,

So people don't always understand this and

00:07:37.250 --> 00:07:41.723
But I may not necessarily be able to open

cause and/or if I'm not

Whatever the case is right,

00:08:05.077 --> 00:08:08.250

00:18:41.870 --> 00:18:44.953
We've been talking about law enforcement
doing the searching up until now.

398
00:18:44.953 --> 00:18:46.508
What about a private individual?

399
00:18:46.508 --> 00:18:50.075
As I've often said, if I'm acting
not on behalf of law enforcement,

400
00:18:50.075 --> 00:18:53.770
rather on behalf of myself or
a customer, whatever the case may be.

401
00:18:53.770 --> 00:18:55.864
Fourth Amendment does not apply.

402
00:18:55.864 --> 00:18:59.064
Fourth Amendment does not apply to
searches conducted by a private party not

403
00:18:59.064 --> 00:19:01.800
acting as an agent of the government,
as I've said before.

404
00:19:01.800 --> 00:19:04.330
Meaning we're not bound by the same rules,
by the same laws.

405
00:19:04.330 --> 00:19:05.298
I don't need a search warrant.

406
00:19:05.298 --> 00:19:07.520
I couldn't get one even if I wanted one,
right?

407
00:19:07.520 --> 00:19:12.340
If I wanna go search Daniel's bag as a

408
00:19:12.340 --> 00:19:13.560
I go search it.

409
00:19:13.560 --> 00:19:17.920
I may or may not have broken his
confidence, broken a law, broken a policy.

410
00:19:17.920 --> 00:19:21.100
But I don't need a warrant to go
snoop around in his bag if I want to.

411
00:19:21.100 --> 00:19:22.632
>> Right, and.
>> I'm not acting as an agent of the law

412
00:19:22.632 --> 00:19:23.230
enforcement.

413
00:19:23.230 --> 00:19:26.156
>> And any evidence you found would be
admissible because you're not acting as

414
00:19:26.156 --> 00:19:27.261
a law enforcement officer.

415
00:19:27.261 --> 00:19:28.610
>> It may or may not be admissible.

416
00:19:28.610 --> 00:19:29.680
There's a gray area.

417
00:19:29.680 --> 00:19:31.091
>> There's a gray?
>> So in other words, yeah,

418
00:19:31.091 --> 00:19:33.461
technically I have the right
to go open your bag, right?

419
00:19:33.461 --> 00:19:35.150
I'm not gonna argue with you about that,

420
00:19:35.150 --> 00:19:39.784
But the issue now becomes,
did I do so with the intent, right,

421
00:19:39.784 --> 00:19:44.871
to essentially look for
evidence without any idea of what's there.

422
00:19:44.871 --> 00:19:47.084
To go on a fishing expedition,
in other words, right?

423
00:19:47.084 --> 00:19:51.571
Hey, I have a thing for Daniel, I'm out to
get him right, and I wanna go in there and

424
00:19:51.571 --> 00:19:53.190

425
00:19:53.190 --> 00:19:56.150
Maybe it's not even that you had anything,
maybe I went in there to make it look like

426
00:19:56.150 --> 00:19:58.116
you were doing something

427
00:19:58.116 --> 00:19:58.840
In other words,

428
00:19:58.840 --> 00:20:02.200
the courts are not just gonna say,
hey, cuz Adam's a nice guy, right.

429
00:20:02.200 --> 00:20:04.890
And cuz he drinks a lot of coffee so
we can trust him.

430
00:20:04.890 --> 00:20:06.370
Right, we had this conversation, right.

431
00:20:06.370 --> 00:20:09.420
You gotta drink coffee to be trustworthy,
right, so you drink a lot of coffee,

432
00:20:09.420 --> 00:20:10.360
you're trustworthy.

433
00:20:10.360 --> 00:20:13.720
So, as a result, we're gonna trust him,
we're gonna let him

434
00:20:13.720 --> 00:20:17.260
tell us what's in Daniel's bag, even
though we have no idea what's there and

435
00:20:17.260 --> 00:20:19.165
no idea whether or
not we should even look at Daniel.

436
00:20:19.165 --> 00:20:22.630
Daniel's probably not doing anything
wrong, he's not up to no good,

437
00:20:22.630 --> 00:20:23.750
he's standing here with me for

00:20:23.750 --> 00:20:27.570

439
00:20:27.570 --> 00:20:31.045
But if I set him up and I put something

00:20:31.045 --> 00:20:34.239

check what's there and they find it,

441
00:20:34.239 --> 00:20:36.053
it looks like Daniel was up to no good.

442
00:20:36.053 --> 00:20:39.829
So, we don't just take the word of

00:20:39.829 --> 00:20:42.390
enforcement, on their
own as a private agent,

444
00:20:42.390 --> 00:20:45.092
as gospel because they could

445
00:20:45.092 --> 00:20:50.210
But we give them more latitude, right, so

446
00:20:50.210 --> 00:20:51.350
There still has to be some sort of.

447
00:20:51.350 --> 00:20:52.010
>> Some justification.

448
00:20:52.010 --> 00:20:52.970
>> Justification.

449
00:20:52.970 --> 00:20:55.905
We would have to go to the owner

450
00:20:55.905 --> 00:20:59.389
we think there's an issue,
we need to take a look at what's going on.

451
00:20:59.389 --> 00:21:01.249
What's the policy,
as I came back to earlier,

452
00:21:01.249 --> 00:21:03.190
or what's the expectation of privacy?

453
00:21:03.190 --> 00:21:05.520
Does Daniel have
an expectation of privacy,

454
00:21:05.520 --> 00:21:09.180
cuz his bag is hanging on a chair

455
00:21:09.180 --> 00:21:10.890
Can I go out and search your car?

456
00:21:10.890 --> 00:21:11.940
Right?
No I can't.

457
00:21:11.940 --> 00:21:15.566
Not without justifiable cause, and not
without a law enforcement official being

458
00:21:15.566 --> 00:21:18.417
present, because I would need
a warrant to be able to go do that.

459
00:21:18.417 --> 00:21:22.028
And/or I'd have to have a law
enforcement officer show up and say hey,

00:21:22.028 --> 00:21:24.915
I think this is going on,
Daniel was acting suspicious,

461
00:21:24.915 --> 00:21:28.450

462
00:21:28.450 --> 00:21:30.560
>> [LAUGH]
>> And we need to check that out.

463
00:21:30.560 --> 00:21:35.090
And a law enforcement officer can show
up without a warrant, ask you questions,

464
00:21:35.090 --> 00:21:39.840
depending on those answers and some other
things that are going on, they may say,

465
00:21:39.840 --> 00:21:41.500
you know what, I have justifiable cause.

466
00:21:41.500 --> 00:21:44.670
I have reason to believe that
you have something in the trunk

467
00:21:44.670 --> 00:21:45.840
that we need to look at.

468
00:21:45.840 --> 00:21:47.630
Are you gonna open that trunk for
me, yes or no?

469
00:21:47.630 --> 00:21:51.516
You have the right to refuse by the way,
but they have the right to either then

470
00:21:51.516 --> 00:21:55.486
decide to open that trunk immediately,
or at a minimum not allow you to move.

471
00:21:55.486 --> 00:21:56.540
Not allow you to touch the car.

472
00:21:56.540 --> 00:21:59.530
Not allow you to do anything until
somebody shows up with a warrant

473
00:21:59.530 --> 00:22:01.280
giving them the right
to go into the trunk.

474
00:22:01.280 --> 00:22:03.410
It depends on what we call
exigent circumstance.

475
00:22:03.410 --> 00:22:05.770
Whether or
not you are going to destroy evidence,

476
00:22:05.770 --> 00:22:09.480
as I mentioned in a prior show,
as a result of waiting.

477
00:22:09.480 --> 00:22:12.050
The law enforcement officers show up and
say, hey you know what?

478
00:22:12.050 --> 00:22:13.690
Daniel's about to drive off.

479
00:22:13.690 --> 00:22:16.390
We could stop you from driving off and
keep you there.

480
00:22:16.390 --> 00:22:19.830
But we may not open the trunk because
we may not have a right to do so.

481
00:22:19.830 --> 00:22:21.365
Cuz it's not in plain view.

482
00:22:21.365 --> 00:22:23.130
We talked about
the doctrine of plain view.

483
00:22:23.130 --> 00:22:27.020
If they see a body part sitting
on the seat of the car and

484
00:22:27.020 --> 00:22:28.790
they wanna know where the rest of it is,

485
00:22:28.790 --> 00:22:31.320
they have a right at that point to go
search your car without a warrant.

486
00:22:31.320 --> 00:22:35.040
But if everything looks comfortable and
just cozy in the car, there's no issue,

487
00:22:35.040 --> 00:22:37.980
they don't have a right to just
open your trunk automatically.

488
00:22:37.980 --> 00:22:41.230
What they do, though, is they have
a right to say, hey you can't leave.

489
00:22:41.230 --> 00:22:42.620
We wanna see what's in there.

490
00:22:42.620 --> 00:22:45.620
We've sent somebody to go get a warrant
and you're gonna have to sit here.

491
00:22:45.620 --> 00:22:46.969
They have right to,
essentially to detain you.

492
00:22:46.969 --> 00:22:47.961
>> Detain you, yeah.

493
00:22:47.961 --> 00:22:52.000
>> And prevent you from doing anything
that could then compromise that evidence.

494
00:22:52.000 --> 00:22:54.850
And it's the same idea when we
apply it to the computer world.

495
00:22:54.850 --> 00:22:58.660
We have the right to prevent people from
using a system with the expectation that

496
00:22:58.660 --> 00:23:03.690
they may damage information or somehow
violate the integrity of that system,

497
00:23:03.690 --> 00:23:06.050
in order to then safeguard the system and
wait for

498
00:23:06.050 --> 00:23:08.220
a warrant to show up to
be able to investigate.

499
00:23:08.220 --> 00:23:10.660
We also have this idea
of exigent circumstance.

500
00:23:10.660 --> 00:23:14.420
And the idea that if you think somebody's
booby-trapped the system, we're allowed to

501
00:23:14.420 --> 00:23:17.560
take control of that system without
having a warrant, to safeguard it.

502
00:23:17.560 --> 00:23:20.910
This is a right that we have
under certain circumstances.

503
00:23:20.910 --> 00:23:25.774
We also, as we said, have this idea of
plain view, the plain view doctrine.

504
00:23:25.774 --> 00:23:29.517
We have the ability to say that if we
walk by and see somebody's got something

505
00:23:29.517 --> 00:23:33.630
illegal up on their screen, we have an
understanding that something's going on.

506
00:23:33.630 --> 00:23:35.030
We have the right to investigate.

507
00:23:35.030 --> 00:23:36.450
We don't need to have a warrant
to be able to do that,

508
00:23:36.450 --> 00:23:40.540
because you made it plainly obvious
that you're up to no good, right?

509
00:23:40.540 --> 00:23:43.691
And so a lot of times when a police
officer pulls you over in a car, and

510
00:23:43.691 --> 00:23:47.229
they say I pulled you over because you
were going too fast back there, or

511
00:23:47.229 --> 00:23:51.028
your taillight's broken, or whatever

512
00:23:51.028 --> 00:23:53.043
And what they may be
doing is just looking for

513
00:23:53.043 --> 00:23:56.324
an opportunity to stop you because
you've been acting suspiciously.

514
00:23:56.324 --> 00:23:58.250
Maybe they've been following you for
a while.

515
00:23:58.250 --> 00:24:00.120
Maybe you're driving too slow,

516
00:24:00.120 --> 00:24:03.138
a lot of times they can't
just pull you over for that.

517
00:24:03.138 --> 00:24:06.934
So they'll pull you over and say something
like well, we thought you were doing this,

518
00:24:06.934 --> 00:24:10.319
but what they really want is they want to

519
00:24:10.319 --> 00:24:13.906
And they want to be able to look in the
car and see if there's anything in plain

00:24:13.906 --> 00:24:17.834
view that would give them the opportunity
to become suspicious and say essentially

521
00:24:17.834 --> 00:24:21.087
hey guess what, based on the fact
that we see this suspicious thing,

522
00:24:21.087 --> 00:24:24.280
we're gonna now search this car,
we have justifiable cause.

523
00:24:24.280 --> 00:24:26.400
They don't need a warrant to do that.

524
00:24:26.400 --> 00:24:29.770
>> I actually saw, I think it was
the ACLU video that said if you

00:24:29.770 --> 00:24:33.250
get out of your car to speak with
a law enforcement officer and

00:24:33.250 --> 00:24:38.070
you don't lock the doors, it's an
unattended vehicle and they can search it.

527
00:24:38.070 --> 00:24:40.770
>> Absolutely, because it's essentially
considered an abandoned vehicle.

528
00:24:40.770 --> 00:24:42.740
It's unattended,
they don't need a warrant or

529
00:24:42.740 --> 00:24:47.170
they don't need the consent of

530
00:24:47.170 --> 00:24:50.440
Which is why if you find a parked car on

00:24:50.440 --> 00:24:53.280
they'll pop the lock, they'll tag it and

00:24:53.280 --> 00:24:56.020

533
00:24:56.020 --> 00:24:59.940
So yeah, it's a big deal, and
I'm not saying this in a negative way.

534
00:24:59.940 --> 00:25:03.070
Firmly support our police officers,
firmly support law enforcement.

535
00:25:03.070 --> 00:25:07.080
Just pointing out that these days with
all the craziness that's going on in our

536
00:25:07.080 --> 00:25:10.940
world, on both sides, both for
us as people that are being protected and,

537
00:25:10.940 --> 00:25:13.970
fairly, for law enforcement officers
that are doing the protecting.

538
00:25:13.970 --> 00:25:16.720
It's such a dangerous thing
to get out of your car today,

539
00:25:16.720 --> 00:25:18.620
on both sides of that conversation.

540
00:25:18.620 --> 00:25:21.470
Because the law enforcement officer
doesn't know what your intentions are,

00:25:21.470 --> 00:25:22.360
to be fair.

00:25:22.360 --> 00:25:26.000
And they may not understand

00:25:26.000 --> 00:25:27.440

00:25:27.440 --> 00:25:29.350
They make it clear they'd prefer you stay

00:25:29.350 --> 00:25:30.071

00:25:30.071 --> 00:25:32.345

00:25:32.345 --> 00:25:33.682
But it's just not a good idea,

00:25:33.682 --> 00:25:36.560
it's not like it was years ago where

00:25:36.560 --> 00:25:39.740

00:25:39.740 --> 00:25:42.330
Unfortunately, it's not

00:25:42.330 --> 00:25:45.250
And so it's really important for you to

00:25:45.250 --> 00:25:48.490

00:25:48.490 --> 00:25:50.600
While you're talking to

my partner's gonna go take a look

Unless they ask you to get out of the car,

00:25:56.440 --> 00:26:01.130

00:26:01.130 --> 00:26:02.100
And you have, you have kids,

00:26:02.100 --> 00:26:03.494

00:26:03.494 --> 00:26:05.290

00:26:05.290 --> 00:26:08.300

00:26:08.300 --> 00:26:10.490

00:26:10.490 --> 00:26:13.450

00:26:13.450 --> 00:26:16.340

00:26:16.340 --> 00:26:20.175
You don't get out of a car just

00:26:20.175 --> 00:26:22.275

00:26:22.275 --> 00:26:24.435

00:26:24.435 --> 00:26:27.595
And it's not just here in the US, I mean

00:26:27.595 --> 00:26:28.595

00:26:28.595 --> 00:26:30.398
>> And maybe not intentionally

00:26:30.398 --> 00:26:31.705

00:26:31.705 --> 00:26:34.185

00:26:34.185 --> 00:26:38.345
They think you may pose a threat to

00:26:41.260 --> 00:26:44.710

00:26:50.720 --> 00:26:53.130

00:26:53.130 --> 00:26:54.210
So just keep that in mind.

579
00:26:54.210 --> 00:26:57.455
So fourth amendment does not apply,
not apply,

580
00:26:57.455 --> 00:27:02.540
to private searches conducted by

581
00:27:02.540 --> 00:27:03.520
Keep that in mind.

582
00:27:03.520 --> 00:27:05.700
The United States versus Jacobsen.

583
00:27:05.700 --> 00:27:08.300
The framework that
essentially guides agent

584
00:27:08.300 --> 00:27:11.910

585
00:27:11.910 --> 00:27:13.620
So the United States versus Jacobsen,

586
00:27:13.620 --> 00:27:17.430
another big, important case in our

587
00:27:17.430 --> 00:27:21.050
Fact that a person is acting independent

588
00:27:21.050 --> 00:27:24.240
does not always mean that a search

589
00:27:24.240 --> 00:27:27.740
So just because, as I was saying earlier,

00:27:27.740 --> 00:27:31.120

00:27:31.120 --> 00:27:33.250

592
00:27:33.250 --> 00:27:35.680
But it doesn't necessarily mean,

593
00:27:35.680 --> 00:27:38.100

00:27:38.100 --> 00:27:42.580
I may be acting on behalf of law
enforcement without directly

00:27:42.580 --> 00:27:43.780

00:27:43.780 --> 00:27:48.520
A law enforcement officer may have asked

00:27:48.520 --> 00:27:51.600
And then that's not considered

598
00:27:51.600 --> 00:27:55.520
So they are extenuating
circumstances to everything we do,

599
00:27:55.520 --> 00:27:59.580
we have to be very careful, and really
very clearly define what we're doing and

600
00:27:59.580 --> 00:28:03.960
have an expectation of the requirement
in a law under which we operate.

601
00:28:03.960 --> 00:28:07.500
A lot of these cases we are talking about,
a lot of these citations

602
00:28:07.500 --> 00:28:11.270

603
00:28:11.270 --> 00:28:15.705
Most was then probably read
Supreme Court case law all that often.

00:28:15.705 --> 00:28:19.315
But in this field, doing what we're
talking about doing, there are certain

605
00:28:19.315 --> 00:28:22.860
cases you just have to be aware of because

606
00:28:22.860 --> 00:28:24.610
It's very, very important.

00:28:24.610 --> 00:28:27.270
What about the use of technology

00:28:27.270 --> 00:28:31.590
So for instance,
we were talking about Faraday cages and

00:28:31.590 --> 00:28:34.870

00:28:34.870 --> 00:28:38.610

00:28:38.610 --> 00:28:41.370

00:28:41.370 --> 00:28:43.590

00:28:43.590 --> 00:28:46.780
Is that allowable under a search and
seizure law?

614
00:28:46.780 --> 00:28:48.250
Do we need a warrant to do that?

00:28:48.250 --> 00:28:50.650
These are questions that may
not have easy answers, right.

616
00:28:50.650 --> 00:28:54.050
30, 40, 50, 100, 200 years ago, when
a lot of this stuff was written down, and

617
00:28:54.050 --> 00:28:59.050
when the Constitution of the United States
was created, we didn't have these issues,

618
00:28:59.050 --> 00:29:00.630
it was pretty simple.

619
00:29:00.630 --> 00:29:04.430
You either wrote it down on a piece of
paper using a quill and ink or you didn't.

620
00:29:04.430 --> 00:29:07.430
And if you didn't, it was in your head,
nobody knew what it was.

621
00:29:07.430 --> 00:29:09.090
Today, it's very different.

622
00:29:09.090 --> 00:29:12.610
The founders and the framers of
the Constitution didn't envision

623
00:29:12.610 --> 00:29:14.010
the kind of technology
we would have today.

624
00:29:14.010 --> 00:29:15.310
This is why we have courts.

625
00:29:15.310 --> 00:29:16.940
This is why we interpret law,

626
00:29:16.940 --> 00:29:21.620
why this is seen as an elastic document,
a living document.

627
00:29:21.620 --> 00:29:23.970
And so as a result,
the use of innovative technology,

628
00:29:23.970 --> 00:29:26.930
which is the category we talk about
that's [INAUDIBLE] by the government or

629
00:29:26.930 --> 00:29:30.990
its agents to obtain information may
actually require the use of a warrant.

630
00:29:30.990 --> 00:29:33.260
It depends on the kind of
technology being used,

631
00:29:33.260 --> 00:29:35.310
and it depends on the way
it's being deployed.

632
00:29:35.310 --> 00:29:39.410
The key criteria here, the key
criteria that the courts look at, and

633
00:29:39.410 --> 00:29:41.330
this is a case-by-case basis by the way,

634
00:29:41.330 --> 00:29:44.270
there's no standard that says all
the time without exception it's this.

635
00:29:44.270 --> 00:29:47.730
It is a case-by-case
assessment of what was done.

636
00:29:47.730 --> 00:29:49.400
But the key criteria is whether or

637
00:29:49.400 --> 00:29:52.690
not the technology that is used is
available to the general public.

638
00:29:52.690 --> 00:29:53.200
So in other words,

639
00:29:53.200 --> 00:29:57.660
if the general public has access to the
technology then you don't need a warrant.

640
00:29:57.660 --> 00:30:01.210
But if the technology is only available
to the government, you do need a warrant.

641
00:30:01.210 --> 00:30:02.530
So it's kind of interesting.

642
00:30:02.530 --> 00:30:03.390
In other words, for

643
00:30:03.390 --> 00:30:07.130
instance, give you a good example of this,
you know what a pineapple is?

644
00:30:07.130 --> 00:30:08.940
You're talking about the little-
>> Small tropical fruit.

645
00:30:08.940 --> 00:30:10.407
>> Yeah, but
I think you're talking about the router.

646
00:30:10.407 --> 00:30:11.933
>> No, I'm sorry,
I'm just kidding with you.

647
00:30:11.933 --> 00:30:16.387
So, a pineapple is a generic kind of slang
name in the security industry we give

648
00:30:16.387 --> 00:30:17.635
to one of two things.

649
00:30:17.635 --> 00:30:21.250
Daniel was talking about a small wireless
router that we can use essentially,

650
00:30:21.250 --> 00:30:25.100
call it a pineapple, to clone and
to mimic wireless systems.

651
00:30:25.100 --> 00:30:28.950
We also have a larger version of it that's
used to clone and mimic cell towers.

652
00:30:28.950 --> 00:30:33.153
And so if the government uses these
devices to set up a fake cell tower

653
00:30:33.153 --> 00:30:38.247
looking to essentually grab cell phones
and triangulate to locate individuals so

654
00:30:38.247 --> 00:30:42.700
they can serve warrants,
which is what they will sometimes do.

655
00:30:42.700 --> 00:30:45.130
This technology is only
available to the government,

656
00:30:45.130 --> 00:30:48.520
it's illegal to own this technology,
even though there's instructions on how

657
00:30:48.520 --> 00:30:50.695
to set one up and
build one out there on the internet.

658
00:30:50.695 --> 00:30:51.712
These things are not that big,

659
00:30:51.712 --> 00:30:55.460
they're roughly the size of laptop,
they're not hard to manufacture.

660
00:30:55.460 --> 00:30:57.100
But it's a felony,
It's illegal to own one.

661
00:30:58.190 --> 00:31:02.470
If you were to use that technology to
be able to spy on somebody, snoop on

662
00:31:02.470 --> 00:31:05.630
somebody, investigate, whatever, you
have to have a warrant to be able to do

663
00:31:05.630 --> 00:31:10.030
that because it is not commonly available
technology under this interpretation.

664
00:31:10.030 --> 00:31:13.670
But the wireless version, the one that you
were talking about that we can set up,

665
00:31:13.670 --> 00:31:17.520
that is legal to own, you can buy them,
about 100 bucks or something like that.

666
00:31:17.520 --> 00:31:19.190
You can get them online and

667
00:31:19.190 --> 00:31:22.480
you can also see instruction how to
build one yourself for that matter.

668
00:31:22.480 --> 00:31:24.970
It's not illegal to own,
it is publicly available.

669
00:31:24.970 --> 00:31:28.130
You can use that, you don't need
a warrant for that necessarily.

670
00:31:28.130 --> 00:31:31.570
So it's a distinction that's really
important, because it's about whether or

671
00:31:31.570 --> 00:31:33.670
not the technologies in general use, or

672
00:31:33.670 --> 00:31:36.400
whether the technology is only
available to law enforcement.

673
00:31:36.400 --> 00:31:38.350
It's only available to law enforcement,
the government,

674
00:31:38.350 --> 00:31:40.470
generically, then warrants are required.

675
00:31:40.470 --> 00:31:43.690
>> So I bet people are making huge pushes
to make this technology available to

676
00:31:43.690 --> 00:31:44.750
the general public.

677
00:31:44.750 --> 00:31:47.700
So that they can hack around
with it a little more [LAUGH].

678
00:31:47.700 --> 00:31:49.870
>> Well it's one of those
interesting dichotomies,

679
00:31:49.870 --> 00:31:51.590
one of those interesting splits.

680
00:31:51.590 --> 00:31:54.400
And as you pointed out earlier,
the law may change over time,

681
00:31:54.400 --> 00:31:58.240
it's a moving boundary, and
we have to think about this as well.

682
00:31:58.240 --> 00:31:59.030
When we come back and

683
00:31:59.030 --> 00:32:03.850
talk about this in the next episode
in our part duex, as they say.

684
00:32:03.850 --> 00:32:04.660
Part deux, do it with me.

685
00:32:04.660 --> 00:32:05.420
>> Part deux.

686
00:32:05.420 --> 00:32:07.000
>> Part deux,
you gotta do like both fingers up.

687
00:32:07.000 --> 00:32:08.630
Part duex, there we go, part deux.

688
00:32:08.630 --> 00:32:12.170
So in part two, we're gonna to talk about
exceptions to the warrant requirement.

689
00:32:12.170 --> 00:32:14.340
You've heard me mention
exigent circumstance.

690
00:32:14.340 --> 00:32:17.100
You've heard me talked about consent and
the plain view doctrine,

691
00:32:17.100 --> 00:32:18.820
we'll talk a little bit
more about some of those.

692
00:32:18.820 --> 00:32:22.645
But things like search as a result of
lawful arrest, inventory searches,

693
00:32:22.645 --> 00:32:26.130
border searches, international issues.

694
00:32:26.130 --> 00:32:29.015
Do you know whether or not we can search
at a border with or without a warrant?

695
00:32:29.015 --> 00:32:29.745
I have no idea.

696
00:32:29.745 --> 00:32:31.365
>> We're gonna find out
when you come back.

697
00:32:31.365 --> 00:32:32.185
>> I can't wait to see.

698
00:32:32.185 --> 00:32:34.140
>> We're gonna tell you,
I'm gonna tell you.

699
00:32:34.140 --> 00:32:34.845
That's what we're gonna do.

700
00:32:34.845 --> 00:32:38.955
>> [LAUGH] Well obviously there is
definitely, this is an interesting topic.

701
00:32:38.955 --> 00:32:42.325
It's a very pertinent topic to our
conversation as being investigator or

702
00:32:42.325 --> 00:32:45.775
someone that is actually
going to need to search and

703
00:32:45.775 --> 00:32:48.185
seize a certain devices and information.

704
00:32:48.185 --> 00:32:50.320
So stuff that you're definitely
gonna wanna know about.

705
00:32:50.320 --> 00:32:51.795
We've got a lot more to go down.

706
00:32:52.950 --> 00:32:55.430
Part two is definitely on
our way as we alluded to.

707
00:32:55.430 --> 00:32:56.585
Adam, thank you so much.

708
00:32:56.585 --> 00:32:58.290
>> Mm-hm.
>> We thank you, guys, for watching.

709
00:32:58.290 --> 00:33:00.840
We're gonna go ahead and
just call it quits for today, signing off-

710
00:33:00.840 --> 00:33:01.840
>> Well, not for today, just for now.

711
00:33:01.840 --> 00:33:03.320
>> Not today, just for this show.

712
00:33:03.320 --> 00:33:04.200
You may have just watched this.

713
00:33:04.200 --> 00:33:05.880
>> We've got more stuff to do for today.

714
00:33:05.880 --> 00:33:08.415
>> Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie.

715
00:33:09.690 --> 00:33:11.668
We'll see you next time.

716
00:33:11.668 --> 00:33:18.060
[MUSIC]

717
00:33:18.060 --> 00:33:21.226
Thank you for watching ITProTV

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam continue their discussion pertaining to search & seizures, this time looking at 7 possible exceptions to requiring a warrant. These include Consent, Exigent Circumstances, Plain View, Search during arrest, Inventory searches, Border searches, and International issues.
episodes.title: Search and Seizure of a Computer Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:06.400
Welcome to IT Pro TV,
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:06.400 --> 00:00:08.458
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.458 --> 00:00:12.424
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.424 --> 00:00:14.344
>> All right, greetings everyone, and

5
00:00:14.344 --> 00:00:16.686
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.686 --> 00:00:19.939
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and today's episode,

7
00:00:19.939 --> 00:00:22.550
well, it's more on our CHFI series.

8
00:00:22.550 --> 00:00:26.776
And joining us back in the studio is a man
that knows no limits when it comes to

9
00:00:26.776 --> 00:00:27.997
search and seizure.

10
00:00:27.997 --> 00:00:29.429
It's our good friend, Mr. Adam Gordon.

11
00:00:29.429 --> 00:00:30.257
Adam, welcome back, sir.

12
00:00:30.257 --> 00:00:30.962
How's it going today?

13
00:00:30.962 --> 00:00:32.019
>> Calgon to you sir, good day.

14
00:00:32.019 --> 00:00:33.710
>> Yes, right back at you, calgon.

15
00:00:33.710 --> 00:00:37.559
>> All right, so all is well,
all is well here in Studio Four.

16
00:00:37.559 --> 00:00:39.587
Let us continue.

17
00:00:39.587 --> 00:00:44.098
Let us continue talking about the
intricacies, and I do mean intricacies,

18
00:00:44.098 --> 00:00:48.550
of search and seizure with regards to
warrants and warrantless searches.

19
00:00:48.550 --> 00:00:51.390
We were talking in the last
episode about whether or

20
00:00:51.390 --> 00:00:54.150
not you need a warrant and
under what circumstance.

21
00:00:54.150 --> 00:00:57.070
Went through this whole conversation,
Daniel was kind enough to help us out

22
00:00:57.070 --> 00:01:00.470
with, with regards to different scenarios,
right, and how they would play out.

23
00:01:00.470 --> 00:01:02.940
And I previewed some of the ones
we're gonna talk about now

24
00:01:02.940 --> 00:01:04.030
with you a little bit.

25
00:01:04.030 --> 00:01:06.060
Talked about exceptions to
the warrant requirements.

26
00:01:06.060 --> 00:01:08.210
And there are definitely exceptions.

27
00:01:08.210 --> 00:01:11.140
There are seven of them, specifically,
that you should be aware of,

28
00:01:11.140 --> 00:01:14.290
especially if you're gonna
plan on taking the CHFI exam.

29
00:01:14.290 --> 00:01:16.315
Might wanna know these kinds of things,

30
00:01:16.315 --> 00:01:17.960
they're categories that
may get asked about.

31
00:01:17.960 --> 00:01:21.985
They're things that as examiners in
the real world, we wanna be aware of.

32
00:01:21.985 --> 00:01:24.160
There's consent,
we've talked about the scope of consent.

33
00:01:24.160 --> 00:01:25.558
We'll go back and review that.

34
00:01:25.558 --> 00:01:29.130
You've heard me talk about
exigent circumstances.

35
00:01:29.130 --> 00:01:31.450
That's why you need to drink coffee,
so you can say that word.

36
00:01:31.450 --> 00:01:32.920
Exigent circumstances.

37
00:01:32.920 --> 00:01:35.770
We've talked about the doctrine of
plain view, we'll talk about that.

38
00:01:35.770 --> 00:01:37.900
Search as a result of a lawful arrest.

39
00:01:38.910 --> 00:01:41.500
You basically have nothing going on there.

40
00:01:41.500 --> 00:01:43.130
They arrest you, pretty much that's it.

41
00:01:43.130 --> 00:01:45.420
You have anything on you,
they're gonna find it.

42
00:01:45.420 --> 00:01:49.830
But inventory searches, as a business
owner when we have inventory,

43
00:01:49.830 --> 00:01:50.840
what kind of rights are there?

44
00:01:50.840 --> 00:01:52.430
What do we do?
How do we deal with that?

45
00:01:52.430 --> 00:01:55.225
Border searches,
I mentioned that at the end of the show.

46
00:01:55.225 --> 00:01:58.740
Asked Daniel whether he understood whether
we could search at the border with or

47
00:01:58.740 --> 00:02:02.640
without a warrant, and I said we would
find out the answer to that question here.

48
00:02:02.640 --> 00:02:05.510
And then international issues, how do we
deal with treaties and things like that,

49
00:02:05.510 --> 00:02:09.330
and how do we deal with cross-border
searches is one way of looking at it.

50
00:02:09.330 --> 00:02:11.820
But how do we deal with things where
we may have signed a treaty and

51
00:02:11.820 --> 00:02:13.580
as a result we may have to give up, or

52
00:02:13.580 --> 00:02:17.440
allow certain things to happen,
and we'll talk about that as well.

53
00:02:17.440 --> 00:02:19.818
We'll take a look at some interesting
stuff that's online to help us

54
00:02:19.818 --> 00:02:20.710
understand that.

55
00:02:20.710 --> 00:02:24.260
So let's start with consent,
what the scope of consent is.

56
00:02:24.260 --> 00:02:28.851
The idea here, and again, we're talking
about the thought process being defined

57
00:02:28.851 --> 00:02:32.918
through the US Federal rules of evidence,
United States Supreme Court,

58
00:02:32.918 --> 00:02:34.309
law of the land in the US.

59
00:02:34.309 --> 00:02:36.078
This is what we're talking about here.

60
00:02:36.078 --> 00:02:39.680
Translate that into your world
depending to where you live,

61
00:02:39.680 --> 00:02:41.710
as I've been telling you
as we go through this.

62
00:02:41.710 --> 00:02:45.460
So the scope of consent
is as defined here.

63
00:02:45.460 --> 00:02:49.690
Scope of consent to a search is generally
defined by its expressed object, and

64
00:02:49.690 --> 00:02:52.008
is limited by the breadth
of the consent given,

65
00:02:52.008 --> 00:02:54.670
according to the United States
versus Pena.

66
00:02:54.670 --> 00:02:59.012
Which is again a case that was
seen in the US circuit courts

67
00:02:59.012 --> 00:03:03.547
probably around 1998 or so,
if I remember correctly.

68
00:03:03.547 --> 00:03:05.294
Gotta stop talking out of turn here.

69
00:03:05.294 --> 00:03:08.036
>> [LAUGH]
>> If I remember correctly, but the idea

70
00:03:08.036 --> 00:03:12.949
with the definition is that we have to
understand that when we give consent,

71
00:03:12.949 --> 00:03:17.280
consent may not be a blanket consent
to search any and everything.

72
00:03:17.280 --> 00:03:19.210
Consent may be limited, right?

73
00:03:19.210 --> 00:03:21.020
It's generally defined
by its expressed object,

74
00:03:21.020 --> 00:03:23.410
limited by the breadth
of the consent given.

75
00:03:23.410 --> 00:03:27.420
If I tell you it's okay to search
what's in this room in Studio Four,

76
00:03:27.420 --> 00:03:28.910
that doesn't mean you can
search the whole building.

77
00:03:28.910 --> 00:03:31.460
It means you can search
what's in Studio Four.

78
00:03:31.460 --> 00:03:35.341
It doesn't mean you can go into
the bathroom, or Studio Five.

79
00:03:35.341 --> 00:03:37.740
It means that you can only
search what's in this room.

80
00:03:37.740 --> 00:03:40.940
However, if there's something in
plain sight laying in the hallway

81
00:03:40.940 --> 00:03:42.040
between here and there,

82
00:03:42.040 --> 00:03:45.010
you may have the ability to interact
with that because it's not hidden.

83
00:03:45.010 --> 00:03:48.830
It's not in any way
trying to be unobvious.

84
00:03:48.830 --> 00:03:52.140
And as a result, the court has said,
hey guess what, you walk down the hall and

85
00:03:52.140 --> 00:03:55.030
you see something laying in the hallway
on your way to search another area of

86
00:03:55.030 --> 00:03:57.820
the building, you can interact with
that because it's in plain view.

87
00:03:57.820 --> 00:03:59.760
>> Adam, would an unlocked door or
drawer, or

88
00:03:59.760 --> 00:04:03.450
something like that be considered in
plain view because it wasn't secured?

89
00:04:03.450 --> 00:04:06.842
>> Well, you said unlocked,
you didn't say unlocked and open.

90
00:04:06.842 --> 00:04:09.731
>> So unlocked is unlocked, right?

91
00:04:09.731 --> 00:04:13.360
But unlocked and
open is very different from unlocked.

92
00:04:13.360 --> 00:04:15.160
Unlocked is just that, it's a state.

93
00:04:15.160 --> 00:04:18.000
We don't know if the drawer's unlocked or
not because we haven't tried it.

94
00:04:18.000 --> 00:04:21.420
And if it's not something that we
are supposed to be interacting with,

95
00:04:21.420 --> 00:04:24.710
we have no reason to walk up and
see whether it's open or closed.

96
00:04:24.710 --> 00:04:28.615
But if the drawer is open on
a filing cabinet, it's a good point,

97
00:04:28.615 --> 00:04:33.159
as you're walking down the hallway and
the door is open, and you could see in

98
00:04:33.159 --> 00:04:37.283
plain view just by walking by
what's in there, that's different.

99
00:04:37.283 --> 00:04:39.784
Because it's not part of what
we've been told we can search, but

100
00:04:39.784 --> 00:04:41.930
it's also out in plain view at that point.

101
00:04:41.930 --> 00:04:45.380
So it would have to be open, literally
unlocked, rather to use your terminology,

102
00:04:45.380 --> 00:04:48.640
as well as being open before
we can then actually interact.

103
00:04:48.640 --> 00:04:51.500
So it's just, again, there's a gray
area there in the sense that

104
00:04:51.500 --> 00:04:56.320
we have to be very specific and
very, very focused, right,

105
00:04:56.320 --> 00:05:00.740
on our definition, on our description
of what it is that's happening.

106
00:05:00.740 --> 00:05:03.520
Open is not the same thing as unlocked and
open, right?

107
00:05:03.520 --> 00:05:04.304
And so that's something,

108
00:05:04.304 --> 00:05:06.470
or rather unlocked's not the same
thing as unlocked and open.

109
00:05:06.470 --> 00:05:08.000
So we would need to be aware of that.

110
00:05:08.000 --> 00:05:11.560
The standard for measuring the scope of
consent under the Fourth Amendment is,

111
00:05:11.560 --> 00:05:14.020
as we said, objective reasonableness.

112
00:05:14.020 --> 00:05:17.700
The objective reasonableness thought
process is essentially the following.

113
00:05:17.700 --> 00:05:20.950
What would the typical reasonable
person have understood by the exchange

114
00:05:20.950 --> 00:05:23.970
between the agent and
the person granting consent?

115
00:05:23.970 --> 00:05:27.490
In other words, if I say to Daniel, Daniel
do I have the right to search Studio Four

116
00:05:27.490 --> 00:05:32.520
and Daniel says, yes you do, what do I as
a reasonable person take away from that?

117
00:05:32.520 --> 00:05:36.910
Well, Daniel, I'm assuming has the right
to give me that authority to search.

118
00:05:36.910 --> 00:05:39.880
And he said yeah, search anything that's,
or he hasn't said search anything.

119
00:05:39.880 --> 00:05:42.010
But he said,
do I have the right to search Studio Four?

120
00:05:42.010 --> 00:05:42.889
Yes, you do.

121
00:05:42.889 --> 00:05:45.142
I could search anything
found within Studio Four.

122
00:05:45.142 --> 00:05:47.442
There is our console here,
our table, right?

123
00:05:47.442 --> 00:05:49.560
We've got some nooks and
crannies under here, right?

124
00:05:49.560 --> 00:05:51.640
So we may be able to search
what's going on in there.

125
00:05:51.640 --> 00:05:54.090
There's a table sitting over in
the corner, as we talked about.

126
00:05:54.090 --> 00:05:56.440
May be able to search stuff

Let's say I wanted to

And I had to come in through the router,

00:32:31.472 --> 00:32:35.500

00:32:39.853 --> 00:32:42.436

00:32:44.500 --> 00:32:47.570

00:32:47.570 --> 00:32:50.430
Your logging, most likely.

659
00:33:09.919 --> 00:33:13.623
probably you'll complete some sort of
a trace and build a picture of what I did.

660
00:33:13.623 --> 00:33:16.907
So knowing that, if I am a hacker and
I'm looking to do harm but

00:33:16.907 --> 00:33:20.256

minimal at best of a trail,

664
00:33:27.836 --> 00:33:31.627
I would use special tools that would
allow me to either tunnel through or

665
00:33:31.627 --> 00:33:33.470
break through the router.

666
00:33:33.470 --> 00:33:38.200
And as a result of that,
if I can get access to the router, and

667
00:33:38.200 --> 00:33:41.090
knowing a little bit about routers
as Daniel does, I know, and

668
00:33:41.090 --> 00:33:44.430
as hopefully a lot of you do, you know
that there are different levels of

669
00:33:44.430 --> 00:33:47.790
permission you're assigned as
a user in a router, potentially.

670
00:33:47.790 --> 00:33:52.311
There's essentially a root level account
that gives you full rights to configure

671
00:33:52.311 --> 00:33:56.437
the router, to modify configurations,
to essentially run the router and

672
00:33:56.437 --> 00:33:57.499
interact with it.

673
00:33:57.499 --> 00:34:01.261
And then there's a lower level account or
two that are typically created,

674
00:34:01.261 --> 00:34:03.889
that are useful for
just doing some basic stuff, and

675
00:34:03.889 --> 00:34:07.480
not being able to modify configurations,
things like that.

676
00:34:07.480 --> 00:34:11.830
If we're good, if we understand that, if
the person who programmed the router was

677
00:34:11.830 --> 00:34:15.880
not too smart and we're able to figure
out the password for the account that can

678
00:34:15.880 --> 00:34:19.220
control the router, we can do what's
called modifying the configuration.

679
00:34:19.220 --> 00:34:21.370
There's two configurations in a router.

680
00:34:21.370 --> 00:34:25.701
There's the stored config, the one that's
loaded into memory that is essentially

681
00:34:25.701 --> 00:34:29.249
used as the pristine copy to boot
the router or to restart the router.

682
00:34:29.249 --> 00:34:32.307
Every time you restart the router
you load a copy of this config and

683
00:34:32.307 --> 00:34:36.325
you leave the original intact, and that
becomes what's called the running config.

684
00:34:36.325 --> 00:34:38.800
And you essentially run
off that configuration.

685
00:34:38.800 --> 00:34:42.660
That way we always have a good clean
copy and we don't screw anything up.

686
00:34:42.660 --> 00:34:44.990
If we modify with the appropriate account,

687
00:34:44.990 --> 00:34:48.740
the running config of that router, we can
change the way it behaves in real time

688
00:34:48.740 --> 00:34:51.230
without messing up
the stored configuration.

689
00:34:51.230 --> 00:34:54.577
So if you see where I'm going with this,
right, the logic would be,

690
00:34:54.577 --> 00:34:58.101
that with appropriate level of access and
appropriate knowledge I could

691
00:34:58.101 --> 00:35:02.283

692
00:35:02.283 --> 00:35:05.287
I could then go about

693
00:35:05.287 --> 00:35:08.990
I could avoid, probably, other landmines

694
00:35:08.990 --> 00:35:12.377
I could maybe even get into your
SEM system and modify logs so

695

696
00:35:17.300 --> 00:35:20.030
I may or may not go to this length,
it obviously depends on what I'm doing.

697
00:35:20.030 --> 00:35:21.689
But let's just focus on the router.

698
00:35:21.689 --> 00:35:23.257
So I'm coming back out now.

699
00:35:23.257 --> 00:35:26.159

00:35:29.399 --> 00:35:30.460

702
00:35:30.460 --> 00:35:33.540
Well, if I restart the router

703
00:35:33.540 --> 00:35:36.005

704
00:35:36.005 --> 00:35:39.020
It gets reloaded with the store

705
00:35:40.160 --> 00:35:42.518

as a result,

706

the configuration goes back to normal.

707

Now, there will be evidence of this,

708

There are logs that are kept.

715

variables in a scenario like that.

But, one kind of thought process.

One, let's say, just generic idea that

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam continue their discussion on digital evidence, picking up by explaining the fragility of digital evidence. Then they go over the rules of of evidence that will ensure the veracity and integrity of digital evidence. This includes the Rule of Best Evidence, as well as the US Federal Rules of Evidence. Also discussed is the Digital Evidence Examination Process.

you're gonna have a good sense
of what that order looks like.

742
00:36:39.553 --> 00:36:41.835
And it's gonna be really important for

743
00:36:41.835 --> 00:36:45.983
you on the CHFI exam to be able to
speak the process steps and say; okay,

744
00:36:45.983 --> 00:36:50.660
these five steps in this order are what
we need to do to answer this question.

745
00:36:50.660 --> 00:36:53.490
Let's make sure I know that,
let's make sure we focus on that.

746
00:36:53.490 --> 00:36:57.140
It's why we spend time on our episodes,
not just talking about the cool stuff,

747
00:36:57.140 --> 00:36:59.580
and the stories, and
demoing tools and all that, but

748
00:36:59.580 --> 00:37:02.430
we also walk you through those steps to
make sure you understand what's going on

749
00:37:02.430 --> 00:37:04.820
with them, because it's very
important to have that knowledge.

750
00:37:04.820 --> 00:37:07.440
>> That's right, you can't just
play around with evidence, right?

751
00:37:07.440 --> 00:37:08.943
We have to handle it correctly.

752
00:37:08.943 --> 00:37:10.090
>> Well, you can.
>> Well, you can, yeah-

753
00:37:10.090 --> 00:37:11.345
>> But you get in trouble when you-

754
00:37:11.345 --> 00:37:12.270
>> You'd better be prepared for

755
00:37:12.270 --> 00:37:14.820
the consequences of
those actions if you do.

756
00:37:14.820 --> 00:37:17.503
And that's a good thing
that they have given us,

757
00:37:17.503 --> 00:37:19.270
a procedure that we can follow so

758
00:37:19.270 --> 00:37:23.733
that we can gather the evidence correctly
so that it maintains it's integrity.

759
00:37:23.733 --> 00:37:25.629
And then analyze that evidence so

760
00:37:25.629 --> 00:37:29.759
that we can extrapolate any information
that we need out of it in a safe and

761
00:37:29.759 --> 00:37:34.231
secure manner, again maintaining
the integrity of the evidence itself, and

762
00:37:34.231 --> 00:37:38.530
therefore being admissible in a court
case or wherever we may need it.

763
00:37:38.530 --> 00:37:43.399
Adam, fantastic job of reminding us that
there's a whole lot involved when we

764
00:37:43.399 --> 00:37:46.891
are dealing with and/or
analyzing digital evidence.

765
00:37:46.891 --> 00:37:51.790
And it is not just the case of, well,
here's your evidence, there you go and

766
00:37:51.790 --> 00:37:55.320
you submit that into log B and
there you go, we're done.

767
00:37:55.320 --> 00:37:59.689
It's a bit of a procedure, and we need to
be able to follow that and there it is for

768
00:37:59.689 --> 00:38:00.286
us today.

769
00:38:00.286 --> 00:38:04.320
Adam, looking at the clock though,
we've well run out of time.

770
00:38:04.320 --> 00:38:06.790
But anything else about digital evidence
that we need to tell our viewers?

771
00:38:08.090 --> 00:38:10.200
>> There is, but
that's why we have upcoming episodes.

772
00:38:10.200 --> 00:38:11.690
>> Well, there you go.

773
00:38:11.690 --> 00:38:13.430
Gotta love the upcoming episodes, right?

774
00:38:13.430 --> 00:38:15.630
That's, [LAUGH] where you get
the rest of the information.

775
00:38:15.630 --> 00:38:17.130
That being said,
we're gonna go ahead and sign off.

776
00:38:17.130 --> 00:38:18.170
Thanks for watching.

777
00:38:18.170 --> 00:38:20.970
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

778
00:38:20.970 --> 00:38:23.296
>> And I am upcoming episode number five.

779
00:38:23.296 --> 00:38:24.821
>> And we'll see you next time.

780
00:38:24.821 --> 00:38:32.612
[MUSIC]

781
00:38:32.612 --> 00:38:39.160
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam define the role and duties of the First Responders; the initial persons that arrive at the "scene" of a crime. They explain what might be in a First Responder's toolkit as well as what a they should be trained to do in their duties. Finally, they go over some of the common mistakes that First Responders can make.
episodes.title: First Responders
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:01.542
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.542 --> 00:00:06.520
I'm your host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:06.520 --> 00:00:08.517
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.517 --> 00:00:12.377
>> You're watching ITPro TV.

5
00:00:12.377 --> 00:00:14.017
>> All right, greetings everyone, and

6
00:00:14.017 --> 00:00:16.280
welcome to another exciting
episode of ITPro.TV.

7
00:00:16.280 --> 00:00:18.340
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

8
00:00:18.340 --> 00:00:21.427
And in today's episode,
well it's more on CHFI.

9
00:00:21.427 --> 00:00:25.833
And joining us back in the studio again
to disseminate that information from his

10
00:00:25.833 --> 00:00:30.191
brain into ours, our good friend Mr.
Adam Gordon, Adam welcome back, sir.

11
00:00:30.191 --> 00:00:31.671
>> That's better,
now I can actually stand.

12
00:00:31.671 --> 00:00:33.920
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] How is everybody doing?

13
00:00:33.920 --> 00:00:38.940
Sorry, we're just having little bit of a
issue with the floor behind the desk here.

14
00:00:38.940 --> 00:00:41.390
All right, so anyway, now that I
have my feet firmly planted on it,

15
00:00:41.390 --> 00:00:42.110
it won't go anywhere.

16
00:00:42.110 --> 00:00:43.320
We should be fine.

17
00:00:43.320 --> 00:00:46.010
I'm doing well.
Hopefully all of you are also.

18
00:00:46.010 --> 00:00:49.210
We're gonna talk a bit about what
it means to be a first responder.

19
00:00:49.210 --> 00:00:53.770
When you show up as an investigator,
a lot of times,

20
00:00:53.770 --> 00:00:55.760
you may not be the very
first person on the scene.

21
00:00:55.760 --> 00:00:57.030
You may be, but you may not be.

22
00:00:57.030 --> 00:00:58.940
And more often than not,
you're probably not.

23
00:00:58.940 --> 00:01:01.580
There are people that have
gotten there before you.

24
00:01:01.580 --> 00:01:05.750
And have discovered that something
has gone wrong, whatever that may be.

25
00:01:05.750 --> 00:01:08.170
Or have discovered

26
00:01:08.170 --> 00:01:11.040
that there may be a reason to consider
that something has gone wrong.

27
00:01:11.040 --> 00:01:14.270
It really depends on how obvious
the issue and concern is.

28
00:01:14.270 --> 00:01:18.390
But whatever that is, whoever those
people are, we call them first responders

29
00:01:18.390 --> 00:01:21.780
because they are the ones that are on
the scene before anybody else.

30
00:01:21.780 --> 00:01:24.320
Very often it's not
the person that actually is

31
00:01:24.320 --> 00:01:27.760
trained forensically to be able
to deal with what they find.

32
00:01:27.760 --> 00:01:31.530
Hopefully, we understand that those people
are gonna be able to do one thing and

33
00:01:31.530 --> 00:01:34.910
one thing only, which is they will
have the presence of mind, right,

34
00:01:34.910 --> 00:01:39.470
the thought process, the awareness to
not go in and start poking around.

35
00:01:39.470 --> 00:01:42.270
But hopefully simply, stop,
secure the scene, you'll

36
00:01:42.270 --> 00:01:46.530
make sure nobody else goes in, and make
a phone call and or help us to understand

37
00:01:46.530 --> 00:01:49.090
that there's something that someone
needs to come and pay attention to.

38
00:01:49.090 --> 00:01:50.690
So you wanna think about that.

39
00:01:50.690 --> 00:01:56.330
But assuming for a minute that we broaden
the definition of first responder,

40
00:01:56.330 --> 00:02:00.690
to include the fact that
the person that will actually

41
00:02:00.690 --> 00:02:05.310
forensically respond to this event
first will be the first responder,

42
00:02:05.310 --> 00:02:08.250
meaning you're the first
investigator on the scene.

43
00:02:08.250 --> 00:02:12.180
The first security professional that may
have some basic training to understand how

44
00:02:12.180 --> 00:02:16.180
to secure a work station and
prevent any future harm from coming to it.

45
00:02:16.180 --> 00:02:19.940
By either disconnecting
it from the network or

46
00:02:19.940 --> 00:02:22.840
just making sure that nobody
interacts with it, things like that.

47
00:02:22.840 --> 00:02:26.860
If we incorporate those people as first
responders, then what we have to think

48
00:02:26.860 --> 00:02:29.460
about is what are the requirements,
what are the responsibilities,

49
00:02:29.460 --> 00:02:32.620
what are the things that first
responders are often called on to do?

50
00:02:32.620 --> 00:02:34.150
So let's talk about some of that.

51
00:02:34.150 --> 00:02:37.620
So Daniel, if I asked you as a first
responder if you showed up, let's say,

52
00:02:37.620 --> 00:02:41.380
hypothetically, as a first responder,
what would be some of the things you would

53
00:02:41.380 --> 00:02:45.350
think that first responders would probably
need to know how to do or be aware of?

54
00:02:45.350 --> 00:02:48.810
>> At least they would need to know
how to secure the area, right?

55
00:02:48.810 --> 00:02:52.570
To make sure that none of the evidence
gets either tainted or leaves,

56
00:02:52.570 --> 00:02:53.750
that would be bad.

57
00:02:53.750 --> 00:02:56.480
We want to basically cordon off

58
00:02:56.480 --> 00:03:01.250
what we think would be the immediate
area of the crime scene per se.

59
00:03:01.250 --> 00:03:03.720
>> All right and
that's a very good place to start and

60
00:03:03.720 --> 00:03:06.530
essentially what we want first
responders to be able to do.

61
00:03:06.530 --> 00:03:11.060
Identify the crime scene, protect
the crime scene, set up the caution do

62
00:03:11.060 --> 00:03:16.072
not cross line tape that kind of stuff,
put the chalk outline around the body.

63
00:03:16.072 --> 00:03:19.460
>> The server.
>> Around the server right exactly,

64
00:03:19.460 --> 00:03:20.490
preserve temporary and

65
00:03:20.490 --> 00:03:24.328
fragile evidence, make sure machine's
are not powered off for instance, right?

66
00:03:24.328 --> 00:03:27.670
So that we don't lose the dynamic,
the volatile data.

67
00:03:27.670 --> 00:03:30.960
Collect the complete information
that's available about the incident.

68
00:03:30.960 --> 00:03:34.220
Interview people, take pictures,
understand what's going on,

69
00:03:34.220 --> 00:03:36.640
make sure we have an accurate
record of what was happening.

70
00:03:36.640 --> 00:03:39.340
So documentation of all findings,
and packaging and

71
00:03:39.340 --> 00:03:43.950
transporting of any evidence
from the scene securely back

72
00:03:43.950 --> 00:03:48.450
to the evidence lockup or back to the
forensic lab or whatever is gonna be part

73
00:03:48.450 --> 00:03:53.150
of that overall first responder who are
you, what do you do kind of conversation.

74
00:03:53.150 --> 00:03:55.630
So, wanna be aware of that and
think about that and

75
00:03:55.630 --> 00:03:59.340
first responders have to have a tool kit.

76
00:03:59.340 --> 00:04:01.180
We've talked about this before as well,
right?

77
00:04:01.180 --> 00:04:05.830
We have to show up with our magic bag
of tricks and have the capability and

78
00:04:05.830 --> 00:04:07.470
the resources to do our job.

79
00:04:07.470 --> 00:04:11.440
We have to have forensic work stations,
essentially a machine, a portable machine

80
00:04:11.440 --> 00:04:15.400
that we will use to document evidence and
to process information.

81
00:04:15.400 --> 00:04:19.100
So we have to have our operating
system installed, has to be patched.

82
00:04:19.100 --> 00:04:21.300
We have to have our tools that are there.

83
00:04:21.300 --> 00:04:24.860
We have to be able to test all the tools
out and do everything we need to do and

84
00:04:24.860 --> 00:04:27.280
understand how to use that system.

85
00:04:27.280 --> 00:04:31.410
We use this machine that I demo off of
from time to time and I have a variety of

86
00:04:31.410 --> 00:04:34.470
tools that are installed there, depending
on what it is we're looking to do.

87
00:04:34.470 --> 00:04:38.070
The key there is that we have to document
everything we do to build that machine.

88
00:04:38.070 --> 00:04:40.660
Know what's available to us, and
know what we can do with it.

89
00:04:40.660 --> 00:04:43.570
So, that way we understand
how to use it effectively.

90
00:04:43.570 --> 00:04:48.020
Especially, if we're not necessary going
to be using that machine all the time, but

91
00:04:48.020 --> 00:04:50.150
only during investigations onsite.

92
00:04:50.150 --> 00:04:53.310
To keep track of evidence, wanna make sure
we're up to date with what's going on

93
00:04:53.310 --> 00:04:54.780
there and
we understand what's happening with it.

94
00:04:54.780 --> 00:04:58.540
So the first responder tool kit is
gonna be very important for us,

95
00:04:58.540 --> 00:05:02.840
because it helps us to be productive and
be able to do our job effectively onsite.

96
00:05:02.840 --> 00:05:06.300
What we don't wanna do is have to borrow
someone's computer to type up all

97
00:05:06.300 --> 00:05:07.490
the information.

98
00:05:07.490 --> 00:05:09.430
That's not gonna be accurate, right?

99
00:05:09.430 --> 00:05:12.750
Crime scene processing,
we need evidence collection tools.

100
00:05:12.750 --> 00:05:17.520
Things like gloves, we need bags to put
evidence in, we need sharpie markers or

101
00:05:17.520 --> 00:05:20.910
some sort of marker to write
information on the evidence bag.

102
00:05:20.910 --> 00:05:24.440
We need picture capabilities, so
we need a camera of some kind.

103
00:05:24.440 --> 00:05:27.060
Video capability,
we need a video camera of some kind.

104
00:05:27.060 --> 00:05:29.900
Oftentimes today,
that will all come in one device, right?

105
00:05:29.900 --> 00:05:33.060
So digital cameras can take
video as well as pictures, and

106
00:05:33.060 --> 00:05:35.080
you can do either one, traditionally.

107
00:05:36.130 --> 00:05:40.950
We may need extra memory cards to record
that information, extra batteries,

108
00:05:40.950 --> 00:05:44.540
power cords, extension isobars for that.

109
00:05:44.540 --> 00:05:48.270
We talked about lighting being important
if we work in remote areas, right,

110
00:05:48.270 --> 00:05:51.790
we're out on the side of the road
somewhere, dealing with the forensic

111
00:05:51.790 --> 00:05:55.280
investigation of a car accident, we
have to have lights if it's dark, right?

112
00:05:55.280 --> 00:05:56.687
You can't just hold the flashlight up.

113
00:05:56.687 --> 00:05:57.304
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] And

114
00:05:57.304 --> 00:05:59.280
go walking through the grass
trying to find things.

115
00:05:59.280 --> 00:06:00.920
I mean, you can but
it's not very effective.

116
00:06:00.920 --> 00:06:02.436
We may need those big cleg lights or

117
00:06:02.436 --> 00:06:06.080
work lights that you often see on the side
of the road construction crews use.

118
00:06:06.080 --> 00:06:09.210
You may have a power generator for
that kinda stuff.

119
00:06:09.210 --> 00:06:11.330
There's a lot of different
things you may need.

120
00:06:11.330 --> 00:06:15.100
You may need special tools to
be able to extract evidence.

121
00:06:15.100 --> 00:06:18.900
If the bullet's been fired, and
it hits a wall, and it's buried, or

122
00:06:18.900 --> 00:06:20.060
burrowed in the wall.

123
00:06:20.060 --> 00:06:21.640
You need tools to dig it out.

124
00:06:21.640 --> 00:06:23.860
Right?
You can't go ripping the whole wall apart

125
00:06:23.860 --> 00:06:24.540
with your hands.

126
00:06:24.540 --> 00:06:28.550
You gotta have forensic forceps, to be
able to pull something out of the wall.

127
00:06:28.550 --> 00:06:29.650
You may need screwdrivers.

128
00:06:29.650 --> 00:06:31.680
I think you mentioned that
in one of our conversations.

129
00:06:31.680 --> 00:06:33.280
You may have to take apart a computer.

130
00:06:33.280 --> 00:06:33.980
Something like that.

131
00:06:33.980 --> 00:06:35.970
Or unhook cables on the back.

132
00:06:35.970 --> 00:06:36.850
So that kind of stuff.

133
00:06:36.850 --> 00:06:40.730
So different screw drivers,
a hammer is never a bad idea to have,

134
00:06:40.730 --> 00:06:43.320
you never know when you're
gonna need something like that.

135
00:06:43.320 --> 00:06:46.910
You know what I had to go out recently and
do, living in south Florida as I do,

136
00:06:46.910 --> 00:06:49.365
and some of you know if you've
watched episodes with us before.

137
00:06:49.365 --> 00:06:54.450
It's hurricane season half
the year in south Florida and

138
00:06:54.450 --> 00:06:57.170
of all the things that I have and
all the tools that I've had for many,

139
00:06:57.170 --> 00:07:00.980
many years the one thing I didn't have
was believe it or not, a rubber mallet.

140
00:07:00.980 --> 00:07:02.420
And you don't often think about that and

141
00:07:02.420 --> 00:07:04.180
its not the kind of tool that
comes to mind when you say hey,

142
00:07:04.180 --> 00:07:06.460
what's the top tool that
you need in your toolbox?

143
00:07:06.460 --> 00:07:09.370
A rubber mallet is not normally
something that's on the top of the list.

144
00:07:09.370 --> 00:07:12.460
But it's very important when you live in
south Florida during hurricane season,

145
00:07:12.460 --> 00:07:13.830
if you have to put shutters up.

146
00:07:13.830 --> 00:07:16.730
Because you often will need a rubber
mallet to bang the shutters into place,

147
00:07:16.730 --> 00:07:18.320
depending on the kind
of shutters you have.

148
00:07:18.320 --> 00:07:22.370
So, I don't have one and I had to actually
help my neighbor put his shutters up

149
00:07:22.370 --> 00:07:26.680
during this last little storm thing we
had going on earlier in the season.

150
00:07:26.680 --> 00:07:31.890
And another neighbor, like all three of us
on either side of this one neighbors house

151
00:07:31.890 --> 00:07:36.590
we're helping, cuz it was a big house and
he didn't have a ladder.

152
00:07:36.590 --> 00:07:38.580
He had, they had just moved in.

153
00:07:38.580 --> 00:07:40.150
Totally like unprepared, right?

154
00:07:40.150 --> 00:07:41.377
>> [LAUGH]
>> And nothing, and so

155
00:07:41.377 --> 00:07:43.420
we all kind of chipped in and helped out.

156
00:07:43.420 --> 00:07:44.690
So I brought over the ladders.

157
00:07:44.690 --> 00:07:47.130
My neighbors on the other side
was helping him do stuff.

158
00:07:47.130 --> 00:07:49.550
And he had a rubber mallet, and
he was banging these shutters into place.

159
00:07:49.550 --> 00:07:52.615
And I'm thinking, wow, it's like that
epiphany moment, the light bulb goes on,

160
00:07:52.615 --> 00:07:53.962
I'm thinking, I'm such an idiot.

161
00:07:53.962 --> 00:07:57.296
For years, I've been up there
trying to power theses things in.

162
00:07:57.296 --> 00:07:59.546
>> [LAUGH]
>> You unscrew the thing with the drill,

163
00:07:59.546 --> 00:08:00.672
and you screw it back in.

164
00:08:00.672 --> 00:08:02.922
And.
You're up there trying to muscle it down.

165
00:08:02.922 --> 00:08:03.797
It's just a nightmare.

166
00:08:03.797 --> 00:08:05.129
And I'm like I am such a moron.

167
00:08:05.129 --> 00:08:06.810
>> [LAUGH]
>> I wanna get a mallet, and

168
00:08:06.810 --> 00:08:10.450
I'm gonna stand on the ladder, and
I can just give a couple of good shots.

169
00:08:10.450 --> 00:08:11.480
And it's right there.

170
00:08:11.480 --> 00:08:14.340
The other way going out, you just hit,
knock it out, and it comes up.

171
00:08:14.340 --> 00:08:18.660
So now now I have, I am the proud
owner of a wonderful mallet.

172
00:08:18.660 --> 00:08:19.960
And I am now prepared.

173
00:08:19.960 --> 00:08:21.550
>> It's a prize possession, isn't it?

174
00:08:21.550 --> 00:08:24.740
>> It is my number one tool now,
it is just awesome.

175
00:08:24.740 --> 00:08:27.160
So, I'm just actually looking for
opportunities to use it.

176
00:08:27.160 --> 00:08:28.540
Actually brought it with me,
it's in the car.

177
00:08:28.540 --> 00:08:31.640
So if we ever have anything we have
to do with rubber mallets, I'm ready.

178
00:08:31.640 --> 00:08:34.570
I will go get it and-
>> What do they say when you got a hammer

179
00:08:34.570 --> 00:08:36.680
in your hand and you walk around
looking for, everything looks like a-

180
00:08:36.680 --> 00:08:37.830
>> Everything looks like a nail, right.

181
00:08:37.830 --> 00:08:41.160

00:30:55.100 --> 00:30:58.350
We do this in our lab environments like
in your VM or in stuff all the time so

630
00:30:58.350 --> 00:31:00.970
you can't reset the system and
blow up the lab.

631
00:31:00.970 --> 00:31:03.190
So if that's the case you have
to know how to deal with that.

632
00:31:03.190 --> 00:31:05.550
That's something else to consider and
to be aware of.

633
00:31:05.550 --> 00:31:09.070
It's not as obvious sometimes as it could
be cuz a lot of us are used to working in

634
00:31:09.070 --> 00:31:12.100
one environment not necessarily
all those environments.

635
00:31:12.100 --> 00:31:13.590
Just to wrap up a couple of quick things,

636
00:31:13.590 --> 00:31:15.350
what should go on the front
of an evidence bag?

637
00:31:15.350 --> 00:31:17.930
We often talk about gathering evidence but

638
00:31:17.930 --> 00:31:19.740
what are the things that should
often be on the front of that?

639
00:31:19.740 --> 00:31:22.320
I talked a bit about this in
another prior episode as well.

640
00:31:23.320 --> 00:31:27.005
But typically what's commonly there,
you'll have typically five things.

641
00:31:27.005 --> 00:31:28.750
Date and time of seizure.

642
00:31:28.750 --> 00:31:30.954
So we have to date and
time stamp what's there.

643
00:31:30.954 --> 00:31:32.780
Again, it is written out.

644
00:31:32.780 --> 00:31:34.800
Who is the person who sees the evidence?

645
00:31:34.800 --> 00:31:36.090
So, who essentially found it.

646
00:31:36.090 --> 00:31:39.290
You have to write down your name,
and usually sign it, right?

647
00:31:39.290 --> 00:31:39.930
Exhibit number.

648
00:31:39.930 --> 00:31:42.420
You need a tracking number of
some kind for the evidence.

649
00:31:42.420 --> 00:31:43.625
Where was it seized from?

650
00:31:43.625 --> 00:31:47.275
So, where inside the crime scene and
what location, so we know.

651
00:31:47.275 --> 00:31:49.562
And then the details of
what's actually in the bag.

652
00:31:49.562 --> 00:31:53.005
You don't just put a thumbdrive in
there and then not write anything down.

653
00:31:53.005 --> 00:31:55.602
You have to put a thumbdrive in there and
say, USB drive found on

654
00:31:55.602 --> 00:31:58.208
this machine or something like that-
>> [CROSSTALK] That way if it makes its

655
00:31:58.208 --> 00:31:59.614
way out of that bag,
[INAUDIBLE] They can say,

656
00:31:59.614 --> 00:32:02.254
well there was a thumb drive in here
because that's what's written on the.

657
00:32:02.254 --> 00:32:05.436
>> Right, in other words we know what to
look for if it's not in the bag, exactly.

658
00:32:05.436 --> 00:32:08.400
Cuz if you don't have any description
in there, we know there was something,

659
00:32:08.400 --> 00:32:09.349
we don't know what it is.

660
00:32:09.349 --> 00:32:10.415
>> Just not what it was.

661
00:32:10.415 --> 00:32:13.733
>> Unless somebody left a note behind
that said, I took the thumb drive,

662
00:32:13.733 --> 00:32:15.150
I'll bring it back, right.

663
00:32:15.150 --> 00:32:18.771
I mean we just don't know, so we have to
make sure that we have a description,

664
00:32:18.771 --> 00:32:21.473
right, of the item as crazy as
that sounds a lot of times.

665
00:32:21.473 --> 00:32:24.722
What I've seen some people do is
they'll take digital photographs,

666
00:32:24.722 --> 00:32:26.769
whether it's a normal camera or whatever.

667
00:32:26.769 --> 00:32:30.596
They'll take a photograph of the item and
they'll photograph the evidence bag.

668
00:32:30.596 --> 00:32:33.683
And then they'll actually,
aside from the description and everything,

669
00:32:33.683 --> 00:32:35.447
they'll actually have the photograph and

670
00:32:35.447 --> 00:32:38.498
they'll put the photograph on the outside
to represent the item as well.

671
00:32:38.498 --> 00:32:41.548
So that way we know we have the
pictographic record of what was in there

672
00:32:41.548 --> 00:32:42.821
as well as the description.

673
00:32:42.821 --> 00:32:45.215
>> Giving you as much detail as possible.

674
00:32:45.215 --> 00:32:46.168
>> Essentially.

675
00:32:46.168 --> 00:32:49.022
>> Cuz if I had two evidence in bags and
they both have thumb drives in them.

676
00:32:49.022 --> 00:32:51.221
This one was a yellow
Kingston thumb drive.

677
00:32:51.221 --> 00:32:54.158
This was a black Corsair.

678
00:32:54.158 --> 00:32:56.114
That if they just both
just said thumb drive,

679
00:32:56.114 --> 00:32:56.772
you-
>> You wouldn't know.

680
00:32:56.772 --> 00:32:58.568
>> Yeah, exactly.
>> You wouldn't know which is which and

681
00:32:58.568 --> 00:33:00.916
you may inadvertently put the wrong
item back in the wrong bag-

682
00:33:00.916 --> 00:33:01.568
>> Which could change evidence

683
00:33:01.568 --> 00:33:02.135
>> Giving it the wrong ID.

684
00:33:02.135 --> 00:33:03.857
>> Yeah.
>> Which would actually screw everything

685
00:33:03.857 --> 00:33:06.281
up cuz it would have the wrong evidence
tracking number at that point.

686
00:33:06.281 --> 00:33:07.953
The last thing to talk about here,
quickly.

687
00:33:07.953 --> 00:33:10.552
What are common mistakes that
are committed by first responders?

688
00:33:10.552 --> 00:33:13.910
So we've talked about what first
responders have to be comfortable doing,

689
00:33:13.910 --> 00:33:14.490
how to do it.

690
00:33:14.490 --> 00:33:15.438
Showing you some stuff.

691
00:33:15.438 --> 00:33:16.911
But what are mistakes we can make?

692
00:33:16.911 --> 00:33:20.105
Biggest mistake we can make is shutting
down the target machine that we're

693
00:33:20.105 --> 00:33:22.347
investigating before we
capture all the evidence.

694
00:33:22.347 --> 00:33:25.822
Right so, if the first responder
comes in powers off the machine,

695
00:33:25.822 --> 00:33:28.813
all of that volatile data
disappears that's a problem.

696
00:33:28.813 --> 00:33:32.655
Assuming that some components of
the victim's computer maybe reliable and

697
00:33:32.655 --> 00:33:35.065
usable when that's not
necessarily the case.

698
00:33:35.065 --> 00:33:37.308
We should never do anything
on the victim's machine.

699
00:33:37.308 --> 00:33:39.815
We don't sit down and say hey,
I gotta check my email real quick.

700
00:33:39.815 --> 00:33:42.682
Let me go do that while
I'm here investigating.

701
00:33:42.682 --> 00:33:45.079
Bad idea, right, we don't wanna do that.

702
00:33:45.079 --> 00:33:49.022
Not having access to the baseline
documentation about the victim's computer.

703
00:33:49.022 --> 00:33:51.478
We don't understand the make,
the model, the build, all that.

704
00:33:51.478 --> 00:33:52.443
That can be a problem.

705
00:33:52.443 --> 00:33:55.383
And also really important,
probably most importantly,

706
00:33:55.383 --> 00:33:59.533
Just as important as not shutting down
the machine before we gather the evidence.

707
00:33:59.533 --> 00:34:01.783
Not documenting the data
collection process.

708
00:34:01.783 --> 00:34:04.907
Also a huge, huge problem for
us if that happens.

709
00:34:04.907 --> 00:34:06.611
So, want to make sure we know.

710
00:34:06.611 --> 00:34:09.027
Common mistakes that
first responders make.

711
00:34:09.027 --> 00:34:11.878
If you're gonna be thinking about
taking the exam at some point.

712
00:34:11.878 --> 00:34:15.223
You may get asked, hey, what are common
mistakes first responders may make.

713
00:34:15.223 --> 00:34:17.827
You wanna know things like
not documenting fully, and

714
00:34:17.827 --> 00:34:21.733
not being able to understand the capture
of volatile evidence before the system is

715
00:34:21.733 --> 00:34:25.201
powered down are crucial mistakes that
we can make as a first responder.

716
00:34:25.201 --> 00:34:29.183
>> Obviously being a first responder is a
very important job If you are in that role

717
00:34:29.183 --> 00:34:31.852
you need to know what is this
that is expected of you.

718
00:34:31.852 --> 00:34:36.298
You need to know some of the procedures
that you might be tasked to perform and

719
00:34:36.298 --> 00:34:39.285
also some of the pitfalls
that you might fall into so

720
00:34:39.285 --> 00:34:41.316
that you might avoid them as well.

721
00:34:41.316 --> 00:34:45.860
That been said [LAUGH] Mr Adam we are
definitely gone well over the time limit

722
00:34:45.860 --> 00:34:46.456
on this.

723
00:34:46.456 --> 00:34:49.956
But for very good reason because this is
extremely important information for you if

724
00:34:49.956 --> 00:34:53.410
you are in that first responder role,
we don't wanna leave anything out for you.

725
00:34:53.410 --> 00:34:55.421
So it was time well spent.

726
00:34:55.421 --> 00:34:57.936
With that being said,
we have exhausted this episode.

727
00:34:57.936 --> 00:34:59.541
Thank you guys so much for watching.

728
00:34:59.541 --> 00:35:01.023
Thank you, Adam, for joining us.

729
00:35:01.023 --> 00:35:04.558
But signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

730
00:35:04.558 --> 00:35:05.639
>> I'm outta here.

731
00:35:05.639 --> 00:35:07.927
>> And we'll see you next time.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam explore what it takes to set up a forensics lab. They begin by defining a standard forensics lab and explaining what you'll need to keep in mind when planning the setup. Also, they discuss what you would see in a typical forensics lab as far as hardware and software.

We've been talking a lot about what to

What the mechanisms,

We haven't really talked about what that

So we thought it would be a good idea for

toys, and

28
00:01:20.900 --> 00:01:24.680
So, let's start by talking about
what a computer forensics lab is.

29
00:01:24.680 --> 00:01:28.515
A computer forensics lab is going to be
that designated location where we go to

30
00:01:28.515 --> 00:01:32.115
conduct the computer based investigations
that need to take place on all

31
00:01:32.115 --> 00:01:33.424
the collected evidence.

32
00:01:33.424 --> 00:01:37.590
In other words, it's the place where
we can climate control, humidity,

33
00:01:37.590 --> 00:01:40.843
exposure to static electricity,
all that kind of stuff.

34
00:01:40.843 --> 00:01:44.746
It's gonna be where we can safely,
securely, and cleanly examine and

35
00:01:44.746 --> 00:01:46.350
work with the evidence.

36
00:01:46.350 --> 00:01:50.320
And do so in a way that doesn't gonna
damage it or anyway comprise it.

37
00:01:50.320 --> 00:01:52.010
Sometimes referred to as a clean room,

38

sometimes referred to as
an evidence investigation area.

39
00:01:56.610 --> 00:01:59.630
Generically, we just simply call

40
00:01:59.630 --> 00:02:01.090
So how do you set it up, what do you do?

41
00:02:01.090 --> 00:02:04.731
In other words, can I go to the back of
the room here at the little table and
