I mean, I could, but that's probably not
really gonna be very efficient for me, and

44
00:02:12.743 --> 00:02:14.660
it's probably not gonna work very well.

45
00:02:14.660 --> 00:02:18.705
So are there standards,
are there things we should be aware of?

46
00:02:18.705 --> 00:02:20.695
Are there concerns we
would need to address?

47
00:02:20.695 --> 00:02:25.185
We often break this down into a six step
process and say, the things involved

48
00:02:25.185 --> 00:02:28.515
with setting up the lab are gonna be
in areas like planning and budgeting.

49
00:02:28.515 --> 00:02:32.170
Gotta do a lot of pre-work to figure
out what has to go into the laboratory.

50
00:02:32.170 --> 00:02:35.685
Gotta put out a budget to be
able to do that and see that.

51
00:02:35.685 --> 00:02:38.020
We've gotta figure out locations and
design.

52
00:02:38.020 --> 00:02:41.100
Gotta understand what we wanna build,

53
00:02:41.100 --> 00:02:42.971
where we're gonna build it,
and to what end.

54
00:02:42.971 --> 00:02:46.010
In other words, have all the tools,
the technology,

55
00:02:46.010 --> 00:02:50.010
the resources, the power necessary
to drive them, things like that.

56
00:02:50.010 --> 00:02:53.270
Gotta have a secure work area,
so that's gonna be number three.

57
00:02:53.270 --> 00:02:55.409
Gotta worry about licensing
of the laboratory,

58
00:02:55.409 --> 00:02:58.170
we'll talk about international
licensing standards.

59
00:02:58.170 --> 00:03:00.940
Gotta worry about HR related concerns and
activities.

60
00:03:00.940 --> 00:03:04.370
So, how are we gonna hire people,
what do the background checks look like,

61
00:03:04.370 --> 00:03:05.400
stuff like that.

62
00:03:05.400 --> 00:03:07.265
And number six, physical security.

63
00:03:07.265 --> 00:03:10.480
Gotta worry about making sure
that this environment is gonna be

64
00:03:10.480 --> 00:03:12.860
firewalled off physically and logically.

65
00:03:12.860 --> 00:03:17.120
We have access control, people can't
just walk in, interact with our stuff.

66
00:03:17.120 --> 00:03:20.720
Data's gonna be locked up and
stored securely, that kinda stuff.

67
00:03:20.720 --> 00:03:24.348
A lot of times, these laboratories
are in law enforcement agencies.

68
00:03:24.348 --> 00:03:27.107
So they're gonna be behind
a security perimeter to begin with.

69
00:03:27.107 --> 00:03:29.580
They're gonna be maintained and secured.

70
00:03:29.580 --> 00:03:32.443
But sometimes they're freestanding
buildings that have nothing to do with law

71
00:03:32.443 --> 00:03:33.004
enforcement.

72
00:03:33.004 --> 00:03:35.198
>> And the placing of your punji
pits are very important [LAUGH].

73
00:03:35.198 --> 00:03:39.881
>> Yes they are, so making sure
that people can fall into them, and

74
00:03:39.881 --> 00:03:44.980
also not only that, but
sharpening them is also equally important.

75
00:03:44.980 --> 00:03:47.710
Punji sticks have to be sharp,
you don't want dull punji sticks.

76
00:03:47.710 --> 00:03:50.760
That leads to pissed off intruders and
nobody's happy.

77
00:03:50.760 --> 00:03:54.190
If they can't complain because they're
too busy screaming, then nobody cares.

78
00:03:54.190 --> 00:03:56.310
So, that's also very important.

79
00:03:56.310 --> 00:04:00.390
You are a devious,
devious person this morning, Mr. Daniel.

80
00:04:00.390 --> 00:04:01.760
So we do wanna think about all that.

81
00:04:01.760 --> 00:04:03.255
So what does planning look like?

82
00:04:03.255 --> 00:04:06.180
Planning's probably one of the most
important things we can do

83
00:04:06.180 --> 00:04:07.280
in any endeavor.

84
00:04:07.280 --> 00:04:10.280
We often talk about planning to be
successful or planning to fail.

85
00:04:10.280 --> 00:04:12.590
And we have the plan to be successful.

86
00:04:12.590 --> 00:04:16.070
So things like what types of
investigations are gonna be conducted.

87
00:04:16.070 --> 00:04:18.220
What kind of material are we
gonna be looking at here?

88
00:04:18.220 --> 00:04:22.600
Do we need a huge garage-like bay because
we're gonna forensically examine cars,

89
00:04:22.600 --> 00:04:23.680
potentially?

90
00:04:23.680 --> 00:04:27.100
Law enforcement agencies do
a lot of criminalistic work.

91
00:04:27.100 --> 00:04:29.151
So they're dealing with drug busts,

92
00:04:29.151 --> 00:04:32.220
they're dealing with people
shooting each other.

93
00:04:32.220 --> 00:04:36.110
People having car accidents that
unfortunately kill people, and so

94
00:04:36.110 --> 00:04:38.530
vehicles being used in
the commission of a crime.

95
00:04:38.530 --> 00:04:40.090
So they're gonna have to examine vehicles.

96
00:04:40.090 --> 00:04:43.515
They have to have a huge working space and
a bay to that.

97
00:04:43.515 --> 00:04:45.555
They may need a mechanics
shop essentially,

98
00:04:45.555 --> 00:04:48.035
a lift to be able to bring
the car up off the ground.

99
00:04:48.035 --> 00:04:51.355
They're gonna need tools to take
the car apart, that kind of stuff.

100
00:04:51.355 --> 00:04:52.907
That's very different than hey,

101
00:04:52.907 --> 00:04:55.970
I got a couple of computers I gotta
throw up on the desk and work with.

102
00:04:55.970 --> 00:04:59.450
So depending on the kind of
investigations that are gonna take place,

103
00:04:59.450 --> 00:05:01.570
we may need a very, very different setup.

104
00:05:01.570 --> 00:05:05.678
If we're dealing with human forensics,
essentially autopsies and

105
00:05:05.678 --> 00:05:08.934
gathering DNA samples and
blood and things like that,

106
00:05:08.934 --> 00:05:13.710
then we're gonna need a very different
setup than if we're dealing with cars.

107
00:05:13.710 --> 00:05:15.323
We're gonna have to be,
you remember Quincy?

108
00:05:15.323 --> 00:05:17.511
>> Yeah.
>> We're gonna have to be like the Quincy,

109
00:05:17.511 --> 00:05:19.717
MD show,
where we essentially have the morgue and

110
00:05:19.717 --> 00:05:21.519
we have to have the examination tables.

00:05:21.519 --> 00:05:25.597
Or NCIS, you have to be like Ducky,
have your little examination table and

112
00:05:25.597 --> 00:05:26.850
all that kinda stuff.

113
00:05:26.850 --> 00:05:27.890
So we're gonna need all of that.

114
00:05:27.890 --> 00:05:32.220
You need the special lights, you need
the cold room to store the bodies.

115
00:05:32.220 --> 00:05:36.010
You need medical equipment to be able to
draw blood and to do all that kinda stuff.

116
00:05:36.010 --> 00:05:38.550
Very different than what
we would be doing, again,

117
00:05:38.550 --> 00:05:39.620
if we're working with computers.

118
00:05:39.620 --> 00:05:44.236
So, we obviously are focussed on
the digital aspects of forensics here.

119
00:05:44.236 --> 00:05:44.920
But the reality is,

120

00:29:11.750 --> 00:29:14.340

00:29:14.340 --> 00:29:18.510

00:29:18.510 --> 00:29:21.120

In the case like this where we're

00:29:26.290 --> 00:29:27.210

00:13:27.440 --> 00:13:29.030

So we can easily take a look at drives and

721
00:31:13.320 --> 00:31:17.130
just take a look at them visually seeing
what kind of system they're going to have.

722
00:31:17.130 --> 00:31:20.120
Or what kind of a Windows
file system may be present.

723
00:31:20.120 --> 00:31:23.990
When we talk about FAT, remember we're
talking about an older file system.

724
00:31:23.990 --> 00:31:29.180
One, and I asked the question a second
ag really more as a general question for

725
00:31:29.180 --> 00:31:32.180
myself, not so much because any of you or
Daniel would have answered it.

726
00:31:32.180 --> 00:31:34.990
But I said hey, are there anything
special things to know about FAT?

727
00:31:34.990 --> 00:31:38.040
And the main thing to know is that
we do have a size limitation on FAT.

728
00:31:38.040 --> 00:31:42.380
Files, remember on the FAT partitions
themselves, would only be a certain size.

729
00:31:42.380 --> 00:31:47.003
We wouldn't get out beyond, pardon me,
out beyond that initial size limitation.

730
00:31:47.003 --> 00:31:50.973
Whereas with NTFS, files and the file
system and the partition itself can be

731
00:31:50.973 --> 00:31:54.833
much bigger, up into the terabyte
range depending on what we're doing.

732
00:31:54.833 --> 00:31:56.689
So you just want to keep that in mind and
think about that.

733
00:31:56.689 --> 00:31:59.672
Yet another reason we don't
tend to use that very often.

734
00:31:59.672 --> 00:32:03.434
NTFS, kind of a newer concept,
builds on its predecessors.

735
00:32:03.434 --> 00:32:06.393
A lot of features,
things like sparse file support,

736
00:32:06.393 --> 00:32:10.450
quotas for disk usage which is kind
of interesting, reparse points.

737
00:32:10.450 --> 00:32:14.566
We have distributive link tracking,
file level encryption using EFS,

738
00:32:14.566 --> 00:32:15.990
we'll talk about that.

739
00:32:15.990 --> 00:32:20.925
EFS is what is traditionally known as file
level encryption of the Windows world, but

740
00:32:20.925 --> 00:32:25.210
there's a bunch of stuff that is new,
kind of as a feature set for NTFS.

741
00:32:25.210 --> 00:32:27.345
We have a bunch of files that NTFS use or

742
00:32:27.345 --> 00:32:32.490
system files that are going to
be part of the NTFS world, ATT,

743
00:32:33.520 --> 00:32:38.210
RDEF, BADCLUS, bitmap BootLog file, MFT,

744
00:32:38.210 --> 00:32:43.590
which is the master file table,
the record of every file on the system.

745
00:32:43.590 --> 00:32:47.630
MFT Mirror which is the mirror
recovery for the MFT, quota for

746
00:32:47.630 --> 00:32:51.900
quotas, uppercase to convert characters
in uppercase Unicode, and volume,

747
00:32:51.900 --> 00:32:54.300
which is where we do our volume naming and
version numbering.

748
00:32:54.300 --> 00:32:57.530
All these are listed in the share notes
along with a little description of what

749
00:32:57.530 --> 00:32:58.345
each one is.

750
00:32:58.345 --> 00:33:00.380
I kinda just gave that you so
you know what they are.

751
00:33:00.380 --> 00:33:02.550
But you do have those,
you just wanna take at look at those.

752
00:33:02.550 --> 00:33:06.641
A lot of times we talk about NTFS people
don't realize there's actually a whole set

753
00:33:06.641 --> 00:33:09.973
of files that are mapped as part of
the NTFS file system that we use for

754
00:33:09.973 --> 00:33:11.393
structure and management.

755
00:33:11.393 --> 00:33:12.595
So it's good to know this.

756
00:33:12.595 --> 00:33:15.200
We also have the boot sector with NTFS.

757
00:33:15.200 --> 00:33:16.829
And we have a cluster size concept,

758
00:33:16.829 --> 00:33:19.170
we just wanna be aware
of some of those things.

759
00:33:19.170 --> 00:33:22.410
When we format the NTFS partition,

760
00:33:22.410 --> 00:33:28.120
we assign the first 16 sectors to actually
the boot sector and the Bootstrap code.

761
00:33:28.120 --> 00:33:30.380
So remember, if it's 512 bytes for

762
00:33:30.380 --> 00:33:35.240
the allocation of a sector, and then
16 of them times 512, you do the math.

763
00:33:35.240 --> 00:33:38.070
That's the amount of space,
traditionally, that we allocate out and

764
00:33:38.070 --> 00:33:39.400
that we have available.

765
00:33:39.400 --> 00:33:43.790
And then we have a partition identifier
that's going to be like the MBR,

766
00:33:43.790 --> 00:33:47.070
essentially the master boot record
is what we would think of it as.

767
00:33:47.070 --> 00:33:53.920
And it's got a unique GUID, if it's for
MBR, for the old Master Boot Record,

768
00:33:53.920 --> 00:33:59.030
it's gonna be 0 by 07, 0x07, to represent
the MBR and the partition identifier.

769
00:33:59.030 --> 00:34:01.900
If it is a GPT, GUID Partition Table, and

770
00:34:01.900 --> 00:34:05.430
newer thought process,
we've got a rather long unique string.

771
00:34:05.430 --> 00:34:07.692
We put that for you again in the notes so

772
00:34:07.692 --> 00:34:10.468
you can see it's a long
alphanumeric string.

773
00:34:10.468 --> 00:34:13.771
But you'll be able to tell the difference
when you look at the drive if you use

774
00:34:13.771 --> 00:34:15.174
a forensics tool to examine it.

775
00:34:15.174 --> 00:34:19.470
Whether it was set up using an older or
newer concept when we partitioned it out.

776
00:34:19.470 --> 00:34:21.090
So it's kind of interesting to see that.

777
00:34:21.090 --> 00:34:22.480
And then we have the cluster sizes.

778
00:34:22.480 --> 00:34:26.320
In the last show, we talked about the fact
that we have variable cluster size,

779
00:34:26.320 --> 00:34:28.590
depending on the partition
size of the hard drive.

780
00:34:28.590 --> 00:34:30.670
And I said we would run
through those with you, so

781
00:34:30.670 --> 00:34:32.530
let's just quickly talk about those.

782
00:34:32.530 --> 00:34:35.240
We have a variable cluster
size depending on volume size.

783
00:34:35.240 --> 00:34:37.260
512 megabytes or less,

784
00:34:37.260 --> 00:34:41.640
not that you would, when would you ever
allocate out a 512 megabyte partition?

785
00:34:41.640 --> 00:34:45.870
But if you did that,
you would have a 512 byte cluster size so

786
00:34:45.870 --> 00:34:47.980
it would be the smallest allocation.

787
00:34:47.980 --> 00:34:51.710
If you have anything from 513
megabytes up to 1 gigabyte,

788
00:34:51.710 --> 00:34:53.300
you would have a 1 kilobyte cluster.

789
00:34:53.300 --> 00:34:57.028
1 gigabyte up to 2 gigabytes,
you'd have a 2 kilobyte cluster.

790
00:34:57.028 --> 00:35:01.910
Larger than 2 gigabytes, and the reality
is in our world, most of these partitions

791
00:35:01.910 --> 00:35:06.350
are gonna be larger than 2 gigabytes,
you'll have a 4 kilobyte cluster.

792
00:35:06.350 --> 00:35:10.912
So traditional cluster size in most
hard drives, and again, important for

793
00:35:10.912 --> 00:35:13.621
us as forensic investigators
to know this and

794
00:35:13.621 --> 00:35:17.990
understand this, is 4,096 bytes or
4 kilobytes traditionally.

795
00:35:17.990 --> 00:35:21.050
That's what we normally see when
we actually go and we take a look.

796
00:35:21.050 --> 00:35:25.540
Remember, as a result of that, when we're
thinking about that, we're looking at

797
00:35:25.540 --> 00:35:30.100
chunking data in terms of management into
these clusters and working with them.

798
00:35:30.100 --> 00:35:33.280
There'll be so many clusters per drive
as we walk through with you, and

799
00:35:33.280 --> 00:35:35.037
you want to think about and be aware of.

800
00:35:35.037 --> 00:35:38.775
And just make sure you have that in mind,
because it would be important,

801
00:35:38.775 --> 00:35:40.492
in theory anyway, important for

802
00:35:40.492 --> 00:35:44.751
you to have knowledge of the different
cluster sizes based on the partition size.

803
00:35:44.751 --> 00:35:48.080
If you're ever asked about them at some
point, it may be helpful for you to have

804
00:35:48.080 --> 00:35:51.521
a little bit of knowledge about that and
just know what the variable sizes may be.

805
00:35:51.521 --> 00:35:52.910
So it's always good to know.

806
00:35:52.910 --> 00:35:57.410
We talked about the master file table
as being the list of all the files that

807
00:35:57.410 --> 00:35:58.930
are stored in the drive.

808
00:35:58.930 --> 00:36:03.030
It's a relational database essentially
that maintains a mapping of every drive,

809
00:36:03.030 --> 00:36:05.325
or every file that we put onto the drive.

810
00:36:05.325 --> 00:36:07.220
So we just wanna make sure
we are aware of that.

811
00:36:07.220 --> 00:36:10.190
We reserve 16 records in there for
the system files.

812
00:36:10.190 --> 00:36:13.170
All the other records are essentially
just gonna list out the files that

813
00:36:13.170 --> 00:36:14.666
are stored inside the partition.

814
00:36:14.666 --> 00:36:17.190
So we wanna make sure that
you're aware of that.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam bring you more about hard disks and file systems, this time showing you a way to hide and discover hidden data using Alternate Data Streams(ADS). They also familiarize you with Linux and MacOS filesystems as well as the Windows Registry and file encryption.

forensic investigator to be aware of which

32
00:01:13.250 --> 00:01:17.740
is a unique attribute, essentially
a unique way in which NTFS operates.

33
00:01:17.740 --> 00:01:22.040
It allows us to be able to create
an alternate data stream, ADS,

34
00:01:22.040 --> 00:01:23.510
alternate data stream.

35
00:01:23.510 --> 00:01:29.279
And the support for ADS built into
NTFS [COUGH] sound like Dr. Seuss.

36
00:01:29.279 --> 00:01:32.170
>> [LAUGH]
>> Is they're surprisingly from

37

a historical perspective.

38
00:01:33.960 --> 00:01:38.680
Because the powers that be that were
setting up the NTFS file system

39
00:01:38.680 --> 00:01:41.630
incorporated support for HFS.

40
00:01:41.630 --> 00:01:43.550
The file system that's used in Unix,
Linux,

41

and HFS, HFS+ in the Mac OS

42
00:01:48.700 --> 00:01:52.515
So that we would have some capabilities

43
00:01:52.515 --> 00:01:56.950

44
00:01:56.950 --> 00:02:01.060

45
00:02:01.060 --> 00:02:04.170

46
00:02:04.170 --> 00:02:07.170

00:02:07.170 --> 00:02:10.580

48
00:02:10.580 --> 00:02:13.130

00:02:13.130 --> 00:02:15.350
Essentially access the data and

This is the second file.

58
00:02:43.090 --> 00:02:48.140

file by wrapping it with the first file.

59
00:02:48.140 --> 00:02:50.020

60
00:02:50.020 --> 00:02:51.680

The second file is there.

It has substance.

So I'm gonna put data into it, show

00:03:06.842 --> 00:03:10.700

whether we know they're there or not.

68
00:03:10.700 --> 00:03:13.080
It's a hidden alternate data stream.

69

Right, it's essentially not available

70

rather show you whether there is an NTFS

So when we think about RAID 5, we are
thinking about taking a striped set, but

299
00:13:41.990 --> 00:13:44.550
adding a minimum of
a third drive to the mix.

300
00:13:44.550 --> 00:13:48.795
So instead of minimum of two, now we're
saying minimum of three physical drives,

301
00:13:48.795 --> 00:13:49.955
you can see them here.

302
00:13:49.955 --> 00:13:53.300
And we can see that each one is
going to be set up accordingly.

303
00:13:53.300 --> 00:13:57.430
And those three drives are going to
allow us to create a striped set.

304
00:13:57.430 --> 00:14:00.650
Each one of the banded areas
here is gonna represent data

305
00:14:00.650 --> 00:14:03.760
in a 64 kb stripe across the stripe set.

306
00:14:03.760 --> 00:14:08.500
But what we do with the parity stripe is,
we put information from the other

307
00:14:08.500 --> 00:14:13.360
drives into a special stripe, and
we place it across the drives set.

308
00:14:13.360 --> 00:14:16.620
So that way, if one of the drives
were to fail, we could reconstitute,

309
00:14:16.620 --> 00:14:19.840
or essentially recreate the failed drive,

310
00:14:19.840 --> 00:14:22.900
by using the parity information
from all the surviving members.

311
00:14:22.900 --> 00:14:26.800
And so, if we have three drives,
as we do here, A, B and C left to right,

312
00:14:26.800 --> 00:14:28.440
just real simple to reference.

313
00:14:28.440 --> 00:14:32.295
Then we've got a P in one of the stripes
on each of the drives that represents

314
00:14:32.295 --> 00:14:33.745
the parity information, right?

315
00:14:33.745 --> 00:14:35.805
Coming from the other two drives.

316
00:14:35.805 --> 00:14:39.565
So if this is drive A,
the parity information here

317
00:14:39.565 --> 00:14:43.435
is a combination of the information from
drive B and drive C, essentially, right?

318
00:14:43.435 --> 00:14:45.860
And if this is drive B in the middle,

319
00:14:45.860 --> 00:14:50.060
parity information here would be
a combination of drive A and drive C.

320
00:14:50.060 --> 00:14:53.867
And if this is drive C,
parity information up at the top there.

321
00:14:53.867 --> 00:14:56.360
No, by the way,
no significance, no preference

322
00:14:56.360 --> 00:14:59.480
in terms of order where the parity
stripe is, that really doesn't matter.

323
00:14:59.480 --> 00:15:02.608
This is just a logical representation for
you to be able to see it.

324
00:15:02.608 --> 00:15:05.760
This really doesnt equate to what
it would look like for real.

325
00:15:05.760 --> 00:15:08.209
It's not like the parity stripe
on C must be at the top,

326
00:15:08.209 --> 00:15:09.871
that really isn't the way it works.

327
00:15:09.871 --> 00:15:12.643
I just want you to be aware of that,
we're just diagramming it that way, so

328
00:15:12.643 --> 00:15:14.040
it's easy for you to follow.

329
00:15:14.040 --> 00:15:16.830
And you kinda see the diagonal,
and watch the parity stripe.

330
00:15:16.830 --> 00:15:20.940
And then on drive C, that parity
stripe's gonna be constituted, made up,

331
00:15:20.940 --> 00:15:24.170
from the parity information that
reconstitutes, or allows us, in theory,

332
00:15:24.170 --> 00:15:27.140
to understand the information
on drives A and B.

333
00:15:27.140 --> 00:15:32.260
And so as we do this, we operate
the parity stripe, so RAID 5 is in play.

334
00:15:32.260 --> 00:15:34.607
Our data is,
this is your data file, right?

335
00:15:34.607 --> 00:15:38.510
So we see that kinda stretched
across the drives in the stripe.

336
00:15:38.510 --> 00:15:41.722
And then what we see is that each drive,
in theory,

337
00:15:41.722 --> 00:15:44.428
down below, made up of 250 GB of space.

338
00:15:44.428 --> 00:15:47.416
And what we find is that,
as a result of this,

339
00:15:47.416 --> 00:15:52.293
because of the use of the parity stripe,
we essentially, effectively,

340
00:15:52.293 --> 00:15:57.504
are losing one-third of the maximum
storage capacity of the set or the array.

341
00:15:57.504 --> 00:16:01.784
In other words, in theory, if you think
about a three-drive set, We essentially,

342
00:16:01.784 --> 00:16:05.886
although we're using all three drives,
when we add up all the parity stripes from

343
00:16:05.886 --> 00:16:10.285
all the drives that are scattered, we have
taken one complete drive, 250 gigabytes

344
00:16:10.285 --> 00:16:14.710
in this particular example, worth of
storage, and dedicated it just to parity.

345
00:16:14.710 --> 00:16:19.190
So although we have three drives overall
in the set, our drive size, or rather,

346
00:16:19.190 --> 00:16:23.190
our set overall capacity, is actually
equal to two thirds of the maximum.

347
00:16:23.190 --> 00:16:27.880
So in this case it would be 250 plus
250 or 500 gigs of usable space,

348
00:16:27.880 --> 00:16:32.390
750 gigs of total space, but
250 gigs given over the parity strike.

349
00:16:32.390 --> 00:16:36.235
So we could take this out to maximum of
32 drives as well, software based again,

350
00:16:36.235 --> 00:16:39.470
hardware will vary little bit
depending on how we set this up.

351
00:16:39.470 --> 00:16:44.000
But ultimately we're gonna
lose a certain number,

352
00:16:44.000 --> 00:16:46.130
a certain amount of storage
against the parity stripes.

353
00:16:46.130 --> 00:16:48.510
One of the downsides of using RAID 5, but

354
00:16:48.510 --> 00:16:51.450
the upside is if one of
these drives were to fail.

355
00:16:51.450 --> 00:16:52.890
If we would delete the middle drive,

356
00:16:52.890 --> 00:16:57.540
your drive b, parity stripe on drive a,
parity stripe on drive c.

357
00:16:57.540 --> 00:17:00.280
Both of them have pieces
of drive b's information.

358
00:17:00.280 --> 00:17:01.510
Combined them together.

359
00:17:01.510 --> 00:17:04.400
Put a new physical drive
in to reconstitute against.

360
00:17:04.400 --> 00:17:07.233
We'll be able to reconstitute
the parity information and

361
00:17:07.233 --> 00:17:09.430
essentially repurpose that new drive.

362
00:17:09.430 --> 00:17:12.872
Make it part of the set and
reanimate, so to speak, our data.

363
00:17:12.872 --> 00:17:15.500
So, it's just interesting
that this is what we can do.

364
00:17:15.500 --> 00:17:19.380
Now we were gonna build a RAID5 solution.

365
00:17:19.380 --> 00:17:20.940
We would have to have
at least three drives.

366
00:17:20.940 --> 00:17:22.690
And so we would have the drives in, right?

367
00:17:22.690 --> 00:17:24.260
And we would make them available.

368
00:17:24.260 --> 00:17:26.880
Again, software or hardware based,
doesn't really matter how we do this.

369
00:17:26.880 --> 00:17:28.630
It's up to us to decide.

370
00:17:28.630 --> 00:17:31.730
But as a CHFI, we do wanna understand

371
00:17:31.730 --> 00:17:36.080
that we should be aware of the fact that
this can be a software based solution.

372
00:17:36.080 --> 00:17:40.150
Done within an operating system on
a single physical machine or done against

373
00:17:40.150 --> 00:17:44.270
a hardware based array in a storage
solution somewhere out on the network or

374
00:17:44.270 --> 00:17:45.700
whatever the case may be.

375
00:17:45.700 --> 00:17:48.010
And we would then have
to operate accordingly.

376
00:17:48.010 --> 00:17:49.770
Right.
So just be aware of that and

377
00:17:49.770 --> 00:17:52.110
think about the logic of
that as we talk about RAID.

378
00:17:52.110 --> 00:17:55.000
We also have RAID Plus or rather RAID 10.

379
00:17:55.000 --> 00:18:00.010
RAID 1+0, RAID Mirror plus a stripe set,
essentially the values of both.

380
00:18:00.010 --> 00:18:03.650
We bring the stripe set together because
it's very quick, a good access to data,

381
00:18:03.650 --> 00:18:04.985
it's very very fast.

382
00:18:04.985 --> 00:18:07.430
RAID10 because we get the mirror and

383
00:18:07.430 --> 00:18:09.680
the fall tolerance capabilities
as we spoke about.

384
00:18:09.680 --> 00:18:10.730
So when we do a RAID10,

385
00:18:10.730 --> 00:18:15.210
we combine the concept of the stripe
set with the concept of the mirror.

386
00:18:15.210 --> 00:18:18.700
And if we did that we would have
an ability to have at least two,

387
00:18:18.700 --> 00:18:21.770
perhaps more that two drives
available in the the stripe set but

388
00:18:21.770 --> 00:18:25.070
we would mirror the drive right,
the drive set.

389
00:18:25.070 --> 00:18:28.460
And as a result we would use two
drives to create the RAID10 array.

390
00:18:28.460 --> 00:18:31.390
So we would essentiality have the same
kind of solution that we had shown

391
00:18:31.390 --> 00:18:34.300
you that Daniel set up for
us with the physical drives earlier.

392
00:18:34.300 --> 00:18:35.580
We would add all those together.

393
00:18:36.840 --> 00:18:40.120
Remember that when we are forensically
examining a machine or

394
00:18:40.120 --> 00:18:42.110
a group of machines,
depending on what we are doing.

395
00:18:42.110 --> 00:18:45.680
We will often take the physical
drive out of the system and

image it separately using

397
00:18:48.970 --> 00:18:53.240
So when we do this, we have to keep track
of which drive was in which position.

398
00:18:53.240 --> 00:18:56.270
We have to know which
drive was the first drive.

399
00:18:56.270 --> 00:18:59.240
Which drive was the second drive,
that kind of thing.

400
00:18:59.240 --> 00:19:01.810
We're gonna have to make some notes

401
00:19:01.810 --> 00:19:02.970
And we may have to look at,

although it's rare these days that you

403
00:19:05.965 --> 00:19:09.375
But in an older system we may have to
look at whether a drive was a primary,

404
00:19:09.375 --> 00:19:11.320

405
00:19:11.320 --> 00:19:14.960
We have to look at which drive it was and
the bays as we open up the system.

00:19:14.960 --> 00:19:17.946
Take the drive out, was this drive zero,
drive one, drive two,

407
00:19:17.946 --> 00:19:19.155
whatever the case may be.

00:19:19.155 --> 00:19:22.060
So we're going to have to
keep track of all this.

409
00:19:22.060 --> 00:19:26.110
Keep in mind, and we've talked about this
before, the value of photographic, right?

00:19:26.110 --> 00:19:27.470
Where the drives were.

00:19:27.470 --> 00:19:29.790
Understanding what order
they were found in.

How they were cabled up.

00:19:31.170 --> 00:19:33.420
All of that has to be part of what we do.

414
00:19:33.420 --> 00:19:35.420
It's very, very important for us.

415
00:19:35.420 --> 00:19:39.250
It's almost literally like going back into
our a plus thought process about opening

00:19:39.250 --> 00:19:42.790
up a machine, looking at all of
the systems in there, all the hardware,

00:19:42.790 --> 00:19:44.200
the cabling, and everything like that,

seeing where everything is,

I've seen certainly photographs

But I've also seen layout forms,

And they'll diagram out what they found,

they'll correspond that with the

So assume it's done different ways.

It just depends on, what you're doing and

It's the things that we talk about,

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam demonstrate using Steganography to hide data within existing data and then performing Steganalysis to find and extrapolate the hidden data. Throughout the demo, they explain some of the basic concepts of Steganography as well as how to manipulate data files with a hex editor to further obfuscate hidden data.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam begin discussing the use of logs and log capturing along with network traffic analysis with regards to digital forensics. They show you how to use both Windows Event Viewer and 3rd-party log viewers to search through logs for evidence. They also show you how to use packet Capturing software to view the data that is being sent over a network and look for any malicious activity.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam further their conversation about log capturing and network traffic analysis. This time they take a look at the concept of using Syslogs as well as the importance of Time Synchronization using the Network Time Protocol(NTP). They also give a primer on the OSI model, explaining why it may be important from a CHFI perspective.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam finish their conversation about log capturing and network traffic analysis. They begin by discussing the difference between an Intrusion Detection System and an Intrusion Prevention System. Next they explore the concept of employing a Honeypot and/or Honeynet. Finally, they discuss the types of attacks commonly found today that a CHFI might have to deal with.

What they do,

55
00:02:19.240 --> 00:02:20.720
One is basically saying,

00:02:28.460 --> 00:02:31.081

sound said alarm.

59
00:02:31.081 --> 00:02:35.660
The other, the IPS, the intrusion
prevention system is actively

00:02:35.660 --> 00:02:38.370

63
00:02:47.650 --> 00:02:50.600

64
00:02:50.600 --> 00:02:53.850
Maybe shutting off a port,
maybe throwing up a firewall,

65
00:02:53.850 --> 00:02:58.160
things of that nature to end the activity,

00:02:58.160 --> 00:03:02.557

00:03:02.557 --> 00:03:04.450

We got all sorts of stuff going on, right?

84
00:03:53.562 --> 00:03:57.257
But we need to understand as investigators

solution running on the machine that has

86
00:04:01.820 --> 00:04:04.259
A software agent essentially

87
00:04:04.259 --> 00:04:06.310

88
00:04:06.310 --> 00:04:07.649
Scanning the data coming and

89

probably in promiscuous mode.

90
00:04:10.560 --> 00:04:13.300
We've talked about that with

91
00:04:13.300 --> 00:04:15.980
And as a result,
need to understand where to look for

00:04:15.980 --> 00:04:18.420

93
00:04:18.420 --> 00:04:22.268
If we're dealing with a network-based

94
00:04:22.268 --> 00:04:25.649
a mirrored port or span port of some kind

95
00:04:25.649 --> 00:04:28.653
Gathering data across all

96
00:04:28.653 --> 00:04:32.414
and perhaps across the subnet or

97
00:04:32.414 --> 00:04:36.175
And as a result we're gonna have to

98
00:04:36.175 --> 00:04:38.889
to understand the true impact
of all the material and

99
00:04:38.889 --> 00:04:41.000
the data we're seeing in the log files.

100
00:04:41.000 --> 00:04:45.051
So it really is very critical for
us to understand the configuration and

101
00:04:45.051 --> 00:04:49.994
the setup of these devices, right, because

102
00:04:49.994 --> 00:04:54.300
The theater of operations and the tactical

103
00:04:54.300 --> 00:04:58.362
and that ability for us to understand that

104
00:04:58.362 --> 00:05:02.128

105
00:05:02.128 --> 00:05:05.130

108
00:05:10.571 --> 00:05:13.348

109
00:05:13.348 --> 00:05:17.346

110
00:05:17.346 --> 00:05:20.283

00:05:20.283 --> 00:05:22.652
In other words where I am and

112
00:05:22.652 --> 00:05:26.141
And so, I do need to be aware of that,
I do need to understand that and

00:05:26.141 --> 00:05:29.190
I do need to have that

114
00:05:29.190 --> 00:05:33.490
Are there gonna be or is there gonna

00:05:33.490 --> 00:05:38.610
in these devices or through these

00:05:38.610 --> 00:05:39.586
Absolutely.

117
00:05:39.586 --> 00:05:43.578

00:05:43.578 --> 00:05:48.200

119
00:05:48.200 --> 00:05:49.450
We're gonna get traffic, so

120
00:05:49.450 --> 00:05:52.810
live raw stream data,
whether it's encrypted or not.

121
00:05:52.810 --> 00:05:56.330
There's so much information, right,
potentially that we get in these systems

122
00:05:56.330 --> 00:06:00.060
and it's incredibly important for
us to think about investigating them.

123
00:06:00.060 --> 00:06:02.986
The challenge for us more often than
not is do we have access to them?

124
00:06:02.986 --> 00:06:06.030
And are we gonna to be able to, again as

00:06:06.030 --> 00:06:11.360

00:06:11.360 --> 00:06:15.030

127
00:06:15.030 --> 00:06:19.630

128
00:06:19.630 --> 00:06:22.120
That's really gonna be, probably,
the big challenge for us.

129
00:06:22.120 --> 00:06:24.540

130
00:06:24.540 --> 00:06:26.080

00:06:28.330 --> 00:06:33.000
But while I certainly know a very large

00:06:33.000 --> 00:06:36.790
I may not be an expert on any

00:06:56.360 --> 00:06:59.480

00:06:59.480 --> 00:07:02.894

00:07:02.894 --> 00:07:06.510
Regardless of who captures it it's going

142
00:07:06.510 --> 00:07:10.170
How to get to it, how to forensically
examine it, how to draw it out and do so

143
00:07:10.170 --> 00:07:13.420
in a way that it's gonna be sound

00:07:13.420 --> 00:07:14.810

00:07:14.810 --> 00:07:17.820
What I'm suggesting is that we have

146
00:07:17.820 --> 00:07:21.040
that we have to look to partner with

00:07:21.040 --> 00:07:22.370

148
00:07:22.370 --> 00:07:26.440
We may be able to provide the guidance

00:07:26.440 --> 00:07:29.290

00:07:29.290 --> 00:07:33.850

00:07:33.850 --> 00:07:38.408

00:07:38.408 --> 00:07:41.954

Because I don't know enough about

437
00:20:57.340 --> 00:20:58.690
We wanna see that URL.

00:20:58.690 --> 00:21:01.240
We wanna know what's happening there and
we wanna say well,

00:21:01.240 --> 00:21:04.750
that's probably when we go and
we resolve and we figure it out.

440
00:21:04.750 --> 00:21:05.930
That may be the bad URL.

441
00:21:05.930 --> 00:21:08.620
That may be the place where somebody
went and all of a sudden wow,

442
00:21:08.620 --> 00:21:09.940
there's a problem, right?

443
00:21:09.940 --> 00:21:13.830
So we wanna make sure
we're aware of that and so

444
00:21:13.830 --> 00:21:17.470
don't be thinking that not looking at
those URLs Is going to be important,

445
00:21:17.470 --> 00:21:20.860
it's very important, and we have to make
sure we go in and take a look at them.

446
00:21:20.860 --> 00:21:23.950
The last one that I think we skipped over,
I just want to come back to and

447
00:21:23.950 --> 00:21:26.930
make sure we talk about,
is the cross-site request forgery, right?

448
00:21:26.930 --> 00:21:30.750
So this is similar in some respects
to a XSS cross-site scripting.

449
00:21:30.750 --> 00:21:32.190
I want to make sure we
have a sense of this.

450
00:21:32.190 --> 00:21:34.740
When we do cross site request forgery

451
00:21:34.740 --> 00:21:37.090
what we're doing is we're
taking a logged on victim.

452
00:21:37.090 --> 00:21:40.410
Again, you have the idea of the person
that's gonna be targeted is the user

453
00:21:40.410 --> 00:21:44.400
that's connecting to the site, typically
with their browser or something like that.

454
00:21:44.400 --> 00:21:45.620
So wanna make sure we have that.

455
00:21:45.620 --> 00:21:48.190
We're sending information In and

456
00:21:48.190 --> 00:21:50.470
out of the web server on
a regular basis remember, right?

457
00:21:50.470 --> 00:21:53.550
So when I connect,
I say hey good morning Mr.

458
00:21:53.550 --> 00:21:55.920
Web Server I'm here, show me some content.

459
00:21:55.920 --> 00:21:59.820
Web server brings it back, puts it in my
machine and I start interacting with it.

460
00:21:59.820 --> 00:22:01.625
That's standard, that's traditional.

461
00:22:01.625 --> 00:22:05.375
But we often have to send some sort
of information to the web server.

462
00:22:05.375 --> 00:22:06.915
Maybe we stored a cookie and

463
00:22:06.915 --> 00:22:10.725
maybe that cookie is gonna represent or
reproduce who we are.

464
00:22:10.725 --> 00:22:15.100
And as a result of that,
that information Is vulnerable to attack.

465
00:22:15.100 --> 00:22:16.900
A bad actor can grab that cookie.

466
00:22:16.900 --> 00:22:20.810
A bad actor can impersonate either
the web server or who we are, and

467
00:22:20.810 --> 00:22:25.010
then can cause that information to be
used against us if we're not careful.

468
00:22:25.010 --> 00:22:29.860
So a logged on victim's browser sends
information, and as a result of that,

469
00:22:29.860 --> 00:22:34.270
the victim's session cookie and
authentication information are often sent.

470
00:22:34.270 --> 00:22:38.460
Well if the bad actor knows that,
when we're logging in, can't they execute,

471
00:22:38.460 --> 00:22:40.820
essentially, a session hijack?

472
00:22:40.820 --> 00:22:41.390
Get in the way?

473
00:22:41.390 --> 00:22:42.760
Take over our session?

474
00:22:42.760 --> 00:22:45.720
And as a result, maybe then
authenticate or, quote, unquote,

475
00:22:45.720 --> 00:22:48.960
authenticate and
pretend to be us and take over.

476
00:22:48.960 --> 00:22:50.890
And then as a result
interact with the system and

477
00:22:50.890 --> 00:22:54.460
the system thinks it's really us
when in fact it's the bad actor.

478
00:22:54.460 --> 00:22:55.770
And this is a little sleight of hand.

479
00:22:55.770 --> 00:22:56.780
It's like a shell game, right?

480
00:22:56.780 --> 00:22:59.610
Where we're swapping one session for
another.

481
00:22:59.610 --> 00:23:04.930
And as a result of that if the website
thinks that it's a legitimate user but

482
00:23:04.930 --> 00:23:08.070
in fact it's the bad actor,
we may wind up having a problem.

483
00:23:08.070 --> 00:23:12.290
And so request forgery is about
essentially identity theft, impersonation.

484
00:23:12.290 --> 00:23:14.350
Right?
We're impersonating somebody

485
00:23:14.350 --> 00:23:17.380
after the initial swap or
information exchange and

486
00:23:17.380 --> 00:23:20.450
then attempting to leverage that
to our advantage as a bad actor.

487
00:23:20.450 --> 00:23:22.560
Kinda sneaky and
devious when you think about it, right?

488
00:23:22.560 --> 00:23:23.830
>> Insidious even.

489
00:23:23.830 --> 00:23:26.180
>> It could even be said to be insidious.

490
00:23:26.180 --> 00:23:28.785
I may have to do the evil laugh and
kinda do the whole hand thing.

491
00:23:28.785 --> 00:23:30.365
>> [LAUGH]
>> Exactly, do that again.

492
00:23:30.365 --> 00:23:34.010
>> [LAUGH]
>> See, it looks like I was doing that but

493
00:23:34.010 --> 00:23:35.370
I was not.

494
00:23:35.370 --> 00:23:37.680
We wanna make sure that
we're thinking about these.

495
00:23:37.680 --> 00:23:42.170
Now in addition to all these, there's
also the other things, as I mentioned.

496
00:23:42.170 --> 00:23:46.250
We talked about things like log tampering,
why logs are so important, we've

497
00:23:46.250 --> 00:23:50.060
talked about zero-day exploits, in the
sense that there's always code out there.

498
00:23:50.060 --> 00:23:51.520
Though we may not be aware of.

499
00:23:51.520 --> 00:23:53.460
That even vendors may not be aware of.

500
00:23:53.460 --> 00:23:55.350
It could be against us out of the blue.

501
00:23:55.350 --> 00:23:58.043
Somebody comes up with one of
these exploits nobody's seen or

502
00:23:58.043 --> 00:23:58.986
heard about before.

503
00:23:58.986 --> 00:24:02.431
Launches and all of a sudden
bad things start happening.

504
00:24:02.431 --> 00:24:06.680
We may be doing brute force attacks or
maybe trying to brute force SSH May be

505
00:24:06.680 --> 00:24:09.830
able to take advantage of some
sort of form on the web and

506
00:24:09.830 --> 00:24:12.707
you'll get it to render an error,
and if it does,

507
00:24:12.707 --> 00:24:17.390
potentially get information back from
it that may actually be helpful to us.

508
00:24:17.390 --> 00:24:21.610
You ever get one of those random weird
errors where you login to a website and

509
00:24:21.610 --> 00:24:25.400
instead of giving the either
404 error page not found,

510
00:24:25.400 --> 00:24:28.930
or you get the 402 or 406 error,
whatever there's a problem.

511
00:24:28.930 --> 00:24:32.030
What you get instead is get the yellow
page with the red angry text

512
00:24:32.030 --> 00:24:32.840
screaming at you.

513
00:24:32.840 --> 00:24:34.650
>> Yes.
>> The old unhandled exception, right.

514
00:24:34.650 --> 00:24:35.940
But then it exposes,

515
00:24:35.940 --> 00:24:40.390
if you take a look at what's in there, lot
of times it will expose the database type.

516
00:24:40.390 --> 00:24:44.040
Expose the web server type,
exposes the path, exposes the credential.

517
00:24:44.040 --> 00:24:47.110
There's all this stuff that's
supposed to be kept internal,

518
00:24:47.110 --> 00:24:50.120
behind the scenes between
the web server and the database.

519
00:24:50.120 --> 00:24:54.050
And you're not showed to you but the
problem is because the person who wrote

520
00:24:54.050 --> 00:24:58.520
the code, the developer didn't effectively
think through the logic of this error and

521
00:24:58.520 --> 00:25:00.795
we have what's called
an unhandled exception.

522
00:25:00.795 --> 00:25:05.150
Essentially an error that occurs but there
is no instructions in the software that

523
00:25:05.150 --> 00:25:07.170
tells us hey when this happens do this.

524
00:25:07.170 --> 00:25:10.224
And as a result we actually just throw
the error code up on the screen.

525
00:25:10.224 --> 00:25:14.620
Well, the problem becomes that we expose a
very large amount of data when we do that.

526
00:25:14.620 --> 00:25:17.720
I love when I see that on sites,

527
00:25:17.720 --> 00:25:18.910
I don't love it, it's a bad thing,

528
00:25:18.910 --> 00:25:21.980
my point is, as a security professional,
I'm concerned.

529
00:25:21.980 --> 00:25:23.680
But when I look at it,

530
00:25:23.680 --> 00:25:26.000
I obviously understand that
somebody's not doing their job.

531
00:25:26.000 --> 00:25:27.810
But it tells me that there
are vulnerabilities and

532
00:25:27.810 --> 00:25:31.020
concerns there,
we'll wanna be aware of that.

533
00:25:31.020 --> 00:25:35.140
These kinds of things, as an investigator,
are gonna become very important to us.

534
00:25:35.140 --> 00:25:38.600
If we probe the site and we find that
we have all these little weaknesses.

535
00:25:38.600 --> 00:25:42.650
Remember, using tools like the End Stalker
tool and other tools that we've shown you.

536
00:25:42.650 --> 00:25:47.280
And knowledge of lists like the OWASP Top
Ten can be incredibly important for us.

537
00:25:47.280 --> 00:25:51.550
To understand how to, not only take
away information from an exercise about

538
00:25:51.550 --> 00:25:55.580
information gathering that helps us to
zero in on concerns, but also if we

539
00:25:55.580 --> 00:25:59.480
do this proactively, helps us to actually
put ourselves in a better position and so

540
00:25:59.480 --> 00:26:03.100
we have to be thinking about what
the job of CHF file ultimately is.

541
00:26:03.100 --> 00:26:07.220
Is not just to come in after the fact
reactively and address concerns, but

542
00:26:07.220 --> 00:26:12.420
if we're smart about how we approach our,
essentially our job and what we do.

543
00:26:12.420 --> 00:26:15.490
We may be able to offer value proactively
to the organization up front,

544
00:26:15.490 --> 00:26:18.980
because we may be able to assess need and
concern and

545
00:26:18.980 --> 00:26:21.880
then come up with an action plan,
a partnership with others to prevent

546
00:26:21.880 --> 00:26:24.760
the very things that we're being asked to
address from occurring before they do.

547
00:26:24.760 --> 00:26:26.780
And, that would be a very good outcome for
everybody.

548
00:26:26.780 --> 00:26:28.400
>> That's exactly right.

549
00:26:28.400 --> 00:26:31.700
I can't think of too many people that
would be upset with you if you said hey,

550
00:26:31.700 --> 00:26:34.630
while I was doing this forensics
investigation I did find multiple ways

551
00:26:34.630 --> 00:26:37.640
in which you're vulnerable, but do wanna
keep us from having to come back and

552
00:26:37.640 --> 00:26:41.990
pay us more money to figure out
how you got exposed or exploited.

553
00:26:41.990 --> 00:26:43.600
You might wanna close that down.

554
00:26:43.600 --> 00:26:47.540
So they do find those types
of things very, very helpful.

555
00:26:47.540 --> 00:26:49.520
And they're happy for you to do that.

556
00:26:49.520 --> 00:26:54.330
But Adam also brings to
the forefront of our mind that

557
00:26:54.330 --> 00:26:58.545
the importance of staying abreast
of the most common vulnerabilities.

558
00:26:58.545 --> 00:27:03.110
OWASP continually creating their top
ten list is a great thing for us.

559
00:27:03.110 --> 00:27:07.200
You should be visiting it, have a copy
of it, print it out on your desk.

560
00:27:07.200 --> 00:27:09.250
Wherever it needs to be,
just throw it out there.

561
00:27:09.250 --> 00:27:12.817
And then make sure you understand how
each one of those top ten vulnerabilities

562
00:27:12.817 --> 00:27:14.880
are used, at least have working knowledge.

563
00:27:14.880 --> 00:27:19.942
And I'm not saying you to be a hacker and
know how to implement them.

564
00:27:19.942 --> 00:27:23.507
But just knowing how they work and
the theory behind them,

565
00:27:23.507 --> 00:27:26.040
even that will be helpful for you.

566
00:27:26.040 --> 00:27:29.502
And Adam, you've done a great job yet
again reminding of these things, or

567
00:27:29.502 --> 00:27:32.281
at least bringing that to
the forefronts of our minds.

568
00:27:32.281 --> 00:27:35.820
That being said, it looks like we've
come to the end of web forensics.

569
00:27:35.820 --> 00:27:38.770
We're glad you guys joined us today,
but it's time for us to signoff.

570
00:27:38.770 --> 00:27:40.777
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Laurie.

571
00:27:40.777 --> 00:27:42.009
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

572
00:27:42.009 --> 00:27:44.170
>> And we'll see you next time.

investigative perspective we got

41

48

00:02:04.100 --> 00:02:06.180
The simple-

00:02:06.180 --> 00:02:08.990

60
00:02:08.990 --> 00:02:09.872
There is POP, right?

61
00:02:09.872 --> 00:02:13.760
POP, the post office protocol,
there is also IMAP.

62
00:02:13.760 --> 00:02:17.220

00:02:17.220 --> 00:02:20.157

67
00:02:32.050 --> 00:02:38.687

68
00:02:38.687 --> 00:02:40.890
And as a result,
essentially falls into one of those three.

69
00:02:40.890 --> 00:02:43.800
But you're right,
in terms of server types, SMTP,

70
00:02:43.800 --> 00:02:47.140
simple mail transfer protocol,
port 425 by the way.

71
00:02:47.140 --> 00:02:50.930

72
00:02:50.930 --> 00:02:53.900

73
00:02:53.900 --> 00:02:56.870

Which behaves like a file server in

81

82

541
00:24:37.910 --> 00:24:42.540
And then we also have third party tools
as well that can help us identify

542
00:24:42.540 --> 00:24:43.550
that as well.

543
00:24:43.550 --> 00:24:46.640
Adam, anything else we need to
add to our e-mail forensics

544
00:24:46.640 --> 00:24:48.470
show before we close her down?

545
00:24:48.470 --> 00:24:50.900
>> No, no.
I think we pretty much covered everything.

546
00:24:50.900 --> 00:24:52.672
>> All right, well,
we thank you so much for

547
00:24:52.672 --> 00:24:56.530
enlightening our little minds on e-mail
and the forensics involved therein.

548
00:24:56.530 --> 00:24:58.440
And as for you guys,
thanks for watching today.

549
00:24:58.440 --> 00:25:00.530
It looks like it is time for
us to sign off.

550
00:25:00.530 --> 00:25:03.160
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

551
00:25:03.160 --> 00:25:04.010
>> I'm an e-mail header.

552
00:25:04.010 --> 00:25:05.428
>> And we'll see you next time.

553
00:25:05.428 --> 00:25:12.610
[MUSIC]

554
00:25:12.610 --> 00:25:15.693
>> Thank you for watching ITPro TV.

00:03:08.290 --> 00:03:11.605

70

They're like, they're amazed
by whatever I've got held up

whatever it was, to the last year or

>> Right, so

[LAUGH]

>> I mean this is so

headphones coming out to go in or

00:04:05.735 --> 00:04:08.660
So you think through

95
00:04:12.295 --> 00:04:15.980
And as an investigator,
this is the kind of thing,

96
00:04:15.980 --> 00:04:20.160
terms of mobile devices, that we have
to focus on, we have to think about.

97
00:04:20.160 --> 00:04:23.870
Oftentimes we're called in
to do investigative work.

98
00:04:23.870 --> 00:04:26.690
And it involves computers,
especially in the digital forensic space.

99
00:04:26.690 --> 00:04:29.280
That's not unusual,
we've talked about that.

00:04:29.280 --> 00:04:31.470
And we've talked about
the importance of that, and

00:04:31.470 --> 00:04:34.500
spoken to that extensively in
other shows and other episodes.

102
00:04:34.500 --> 00:04:38.480
But a lot of times a lot of information
that we may have to go after will be on

103
00:04:38.480 --> 00:04:39.210
a cell phone.

104
00:04:39.210 --> 00:04:40.850
Think about what you do
with cell phones today.

105
00:04:40.850 --> 00:04:42.810
We call them smart devices.

106
00:04:42.810 --> 00:04:45.580
Dumb user smart device but

107
00:04:45.580 --> 00:04:49.950
And if you think about what you do today,
your pictures are probably on there,

108
00:04:49.950 --> 00:04:54.510
videos most likely maybe on there,
you may do and

109
00:04:54.510 --> 00:04:57.870
use the web browser or
use apps to do things like online banking,

110
00:04:57.870 --> 00:05:01.610

Google Pay or iPay or whatever.

111
00:05:01.610 --> 00:05:03.440
So you may have an electronic wallet.

112
00:05:03.440 --> 00:05:05.460
We can track transactions there.

113
00:05:05.460 --> 00:05:07.950
There's a log of everything

114
00:05:07.950 --> 00:05:09.450

00:05:12.130 --> 00:05:14.720

00:05:14.720 --> 00:05:17.180

118
00:05:17.180 --> 00:05:20.270
Information you may have sent back and

119
00:05:20.270 --> 00:05:22.320
There's a record of all this stuff.

120
00:05:22.320 --> 00:05:25.320
And we don't often think about this but

00:05:27.690 --> 00:05:29.210

00:05:36.720 --> 00:05:39.700
And I'm not talking about like,

00:05:39.700 --> 00:05:43.050

00:05:43.050 --> 00:05:44.460

00:05:44.460 --> 00:05:45.330

00:05:45.330 --> 00:05:48.910

00:05:48.910 --> 00:05:52.750

00:05:52.750 --> 00:05:55.750

133
00:05:55.750 --> 00:05:58.810
I mean, you would think to yourself,
how does somebody walk away?

134
00:05:58.810 --> 00:06:02.420
How do you forget and

135
00:06:02.420 --> 00:06:05.780
>> I wouldn't know at all from
personal experience, at all.

136
00:06:06.910 --> 00:06:07.680
Yeah, I've done it.

137
00:06:07.680 --> 00:06:09.430

00:06:09.430 --> 00:06:10.810
>> Yeah,

00:06:10.810 --> 00:06:13.500

00:06:13.500 --> 00:06:14.900

00:06:14.900 --> 00:06:15.723
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

142
00:06:15.723 --> 00:06:18.127

143
00:06:18.127 --> 00:06:18.760

144
00:06:18.760 --> 00:06:22.550

00:06:22.550 --> 00:06:24.500

00:06:24.500 --> 00:06:25.590

00:06:25.590 --> 00:06:27.830
I was over there doing work.

00:06:27.830 --> 00:06:29.980
I, actually, was running between flights,

00:06:29.980 --> 00:06:34.360

150
00:06:34.360 --> 00:06:39.070
I may have been going over to,
I don't even know.

151
00:06:39.070 --> 00:06:41.880
I was going somewhere, I think I may
have been going from Delhi to Mumbai,

152
00:06:41.880 --> 00:06:43.620
or Mumbai to Delhi or whatever it was.

153
00:06:43.620 --> 00:06:47.880
But I was on an internal flight, not on, I

154
00:06:47.880 --> 00:06:50.150
one of their internal
carriers inside the country.

155
00:06:50.150 --> 00:06:51.910
And I was in the departure lounge.

156
00:06:51.910 --> 00:06:54.030
I was doing a bunch of stuff

157
00:06:54.030 --> 00:06:58.530
They called the plane and I grabbed,
I thought I grabbed everything, I got

00:06:58.530 --> 00:07:02.000

00:07:02.000 --> 00:07:03.250

00:07:03.250 --> 00:07:07.490

00:07:07.490 --> 00:07:11.670
Luckily, it was able to call from

162
00:07:11.670 --> 00:07:13.400
They had found it, they held it.

163
00:07:13.400 --> 00:07:15.360
I actually wound up doing
like whatever I was doing.

164
00:07:15.360 --> 00:07:17.325
Made the trip back like two days later.

165
00:07:17.325 --> 00:07:20.145
I had to go back to pick it up
at that point, at the airport.

166
00:07:20.145 --> 00:07:21.195
But I was able to go pick it up.

167
00:07:21.195 --> 00:07:22.395
They actually had it.

168
00:07:22.395 --> 00:07:23.855
So I've been there and done that too.

169
00:07:23.855 --> 00:07:25.415
I can totally sympathize with you.

170
00:07:25.415 --> 00:07:30.275
But the reality's just, you wonder a lot
of times, what happens in someone's mind.

171
00:07:30.275 --> 00:07:33.005
How are they so
distracted that they forget that, right?

172
00:07:33.005 --> 00:07:34.125
Wait till you forget the kid.

173
00:07:34.125 --> 00:07:34.965
Forget about the laptop.

174
00:07:34.965 --> 00:07:35.974
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

175
00:07:35.974 --> 00:07:36.506
>> Wait till you get out of

176
00:07:36.506 --> 00:07:37.215
the car, and forget the kid.

177
00:07:37.215 --> 00:07:38.437
>> I'd never let that happen.

178
00:07:38.437 --> 00:07:39.966
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, you say that now.

179
00:07:39.966 --> 00:07:40.910
But just wait.

180
00:07:40.910 --> 00:07:43.244
Hopefully the wife's not around,
you go get the kid and

181
00:07:43.244 --> 00:07:45.338
make a big joke out of it
before they figure it out.

182
00:07:45.338 --> 00:07:49.219
But the reality is, right, that this stuff
happens and so as investigators a lot of

183
00:07:49.219 --> 00:07:52.503

to figure out what's going on here.

184
00:07:52.503 --> 00:07:56.323
So I wanna start by breaking down what the
components of a cellular network look like

00:07:56.323 --> 00:07:58.849
We often think about, hey,
I wanna make a phone call.

186
00:07:58.849 --> 00:08:01.640

what it means to make a phone call?

187
00:08:01.640 --> 00:08:02.650
Or do you just make a phone call?

188
00:08:02.650 --> 00:08:05.990

189
00:08:05.990 --> 00:08:06.850
What are the moving parts?

190
00:08:06.850 --> 00:08:09.107
What's the architecture
of the cellphone network?

191
00:08:09.107 --> 00:08:10.680
We're gonna break that down for you.

192
00:08:10.680 --> 00:08:12.566
We'll talk about what the different
types of cell networks are.

193
00:08:12.566 --> 00:08:16.000
There's over ten types you can connect to
depending on where you are in the world.

194
00:08:16.000 --> 00:08:17.710
Probably important to know about that.

195
00:08:17.710 --> 00:08:20.560
We'll talk about some of
the interesting moving parts and

196
00:08:20.560 --> 00:08:22.225
pieces that identify a phone.

197
00:08:22.225 --> 00:08:26.490
Daniel's been kind enough to volunteer his
personal property for demonstration, and

00:08:26.490 --> 00:08:28.330
we're gonna take a look some stuff there.

199
00:08:28.330 --> 00:08:34.090
We'll use the zoom in capability
sky/sock came here in studio four.

00:08:34.090 --> 00:08:37.220
And we'll take a look at that, and
we'll show you some tips and tricks.

201
00:08:37.220 --> 00:08:39.490
I'm gonna demo a little
piece of software for you.

202
00:08:39.490 --> 00:08:42.950
Give you a taste of what it looks like
to actually engage in mobile forensics,

203
00:08:42.950 --> 00:08:46.680
in terms of the some of the new software
we can use to examine systems and

204
00:08:46.680 --> 00:08:48.510

information we may find.

Let's start with the components
of a cellular network.

So do you know how many components

00:08:56.565 --> 00:08:57.232

>> I will-
>> You're not supposed to

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam talk about what's involved in creating official reports and acting as an expert witness. They explain what qualifies a person as an expert witness to be considered for that duty. Finally, they take a look at an example of what an official CHFI report consists of.
episodes.title: Reports and Testimony

00:02:40.182 --> 00:02:42.966
And whatever they may have on

almost without exception,

00:02:45.376 --> 00:02:48.042
There may be slight variations, but
